reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've never been much of an online multiplayer kind of guy, in my household we couch co-op and that's just always been our tradition. Playing side by side with friends and family, bulky plastic controllers in hand is a lost art and one that deserves a lot more attention. We've seen many titles try and bring back this passion for a more human gaming experience in the living room recently with successful titles like Nidhogg and TowerFall Ascension reminding us of that feeling of intense person-to-person competition and friendly rivalry we were able to get with console games in the past. With the rising popularity of online PC gaming where does this close and personal human interaction go, is there still room for the local multiplayer experience?

Crawl thinks so, and it answers the call by pitting man against monster, friend against friend, in the darkest and nethermost of dungeons of the most replayable player on player brawler to date. You will die many times by the hands of your most trusted acquaintances but as Bram Stoker once wrote, We learn from failure

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NO! NOT MY SLIME!!!

This game, is simply fantastic. Its a simple concept, but its a good one. You and up to 3 friends will scramble to kill the hero, or stay alive as him. You will get better gear, evolve your monsters into stronger ones, and in the end, control or fight a massive boss monster. Its ok by yourself, I can recommend it if you dont have at least one friend to play with. But with a full group, prepare for yelling, insults and tons of good laughs. The only thing that kills me, is the lack of online multiplayer. If that was here, whats to stop this game from being the best game on steam?

10/10 would steal slimes again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Recipe for Crawl goes something like this:
• a dash of inverted D&D (one player, three DMs)
• a sprinkle of Tag
• a cup of Legend of Zelda
• three tablespoons Altered Beast
• 20 pounds of arcade nostalgia

The goal is simple: kill the final boss and regain your humanity. However, there's only one soul to have and four greedy dead paws trying to grab it. Who has the humanity now? Everybody gang up and kill him. Killing blow takes the soul. This pattern repeats itself until somebody becomes powerful enough to face the final boss. Whether they succeed or not depends on the skill of all involved.

This is some of the best couch entertainment I've seen in a while. It tickles my heart with its presentation, seeming so serious but hinting at its self-awareness.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!

For the longest time now publishers and devs have decided that gamers no longer have friends in real life... our social gaming lives exist solely online. This has lead to the downfall of “couch co-op,” with many multiplayer games being released completely lacking any local multiplayer feature. It's time we say enough is enough! I still have buds over to play video games, real ones that stay too late and often drink too much (Hey Will! Sure, what kind of party would it be if you didn't vomit everywhere?).

The devs of “Crawl” remember the yesteryear of “couch co-op” and they hear our cries. Like silent, brooding Batman-y types they're the heroes local multiplayer deserves; and they're paying an homage to classic, “Gauntlet” type dungeon crawlers. The concept is simple: you and up to three friends select a god to represent (you can also use bots that are HIGHLY competent). Each god represents different creatures you'll take the form of during battle so choose wisely. Then you're dropped into the first level of the dungeon. One player is the hero, the rest of you are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ specters of death who's sole purpose is to thwart the crawler with traps and dark symbols through which you become corporeal monsters. First player to kill the crawler becomes one themselves, and the cycle continues. Be warned: “Crawl” has friendship killing potential the likes of which haven't been seen since “Mario Party,” “Mario Kart,” and the little-known “Mario ♥♥♥♥s Your Friend's Mother.”

Throughout each dungeon you'll gather gold to spend on upgrades and weapons. As you clear each section you'll use vitae gathered to “evolve” your monsters, branching off into more powerful ranged, magic, and warrior types. Each level also features an ominous Stonehenge-like monument pulsating with blue magicka that unlocks the final boss once you or one of your former pals reach level 10. At that point you can choose to face the big baddie. You'll get a cool battle strategy hint in the boss fountain room before entering the arena. Each of your friends (and bots) will possess the boss, working in tandem to stop you from winning by using a variety of attacks. Assuming you win it's game over, you won! Assuming you lose another friend gets a shot. But each time you face the boss you do damage to the monument and if no one wins you will all game over.

“Crawl” is beautiful, stylish, and a blast to play. The monsters are really cool, the music is most excellently retro, and when playing against three friends (or AI bots with the difficulty increased) it is a challenge. The devs (now famously) sent out a cool apology gif when they had to delay “Crawl” briefly – which to me is a good indicator that they will work with the community to continue expanding and polishing an already excellent core game.

ALAS, I have one major gripe. It isn't a deal breaker, not for me anyway. But at the moment there is no ONLINE multiplayer. Now I know what I said earlier. I miss the bygone days of local mutliplayer and I'm happy to see it as an option. But I still have lots of friends I want to play this with online, ones that live far away in mythical places like California and Canada. I want to live in a world where I don't have to choose. I want both, perhaps greedily. Hopefully we'll see it implemented. Otherwise keep in mind this is Early Access. At the moment there appears to be one final boss and only three deities to choose from. But what is there is highly polished and very fun. They'll be adding more end bosses and deities throughout development. I also hope to see more variety in the dungeon layouts and color schemes. But as it is this is an excellent title. For ten bucks I easily, heartily recommend this.

Reviewer's Note: “Mario ♥♥♥♥s Your Friend's Mother” probably doesn't exist. Probably.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best local multiplayer games ever made. My friends and I have played this almost every week without fail since launch - it's that damn good. When we meet new people who claim they're into games, we vet them on this and see if they have fun or can appreciate the depth of game mechanics. We love this game because there's nothing like sitting shoulder to shoulder with a pal and howling with rage at a stolen kill, laughter at a horde of slimes causing a human to suddenly play a Shmup, or roars of hype when a close bossfight comes down to the wire. My short recommendation for this game is BUY IT. But now let's get to why you should.

CRAWL is a local multiplayer game that involves between 2-4 players. One player is a human, and the other 1-3 are monsters. Every time a monster kills a human, whether it being done as a monster, as a possessable slime, or a controllable trap, that player will become the human. This has to be done on a last hit. This means that the three non-human players must work in a loose alliance until the very last minute, because there can only be one human!

The other gameplay mechanics are a bit more complicated than that, and I'll explain the most complicated one, the leveling system and the asymmetrical nature of the players:

-A player possessing a human can kill monsters to gain XP and continue leveling up. This primarily adds extra health and to the human and gets the player closer to a boss run, since only characters with level 10 or higher can do boss runs. Humans get better gear and stats by accessing shops. They use gold that they gain primarly while being a monster (I'll get to that later)

-Nonhuman players control ghosts most of the time. Ghosts can possess pentagrams to spawn as monsters and fight the humans. They can also control traps or collect ectoplasm while they're in Ghost mode to drop slimes, which are weak, autonomous/controllable monsters that can be dropped at any time. This is useful for trapping a human in a room, since humans must kill all monsters before leaving a room. Slimes aren't too strong on their own, but if the human's health is low, and/or the room is full of traps, they can be utterly devastating. All players can level up their monsters at the end of a round. Nonhuman players can also all control a boss monster Voltron-style, with each player controlling a limb or head and working together to kill the human.

Now here's what keeps this asymmetrical gameplay balanced from a progression standpoint. As other players level up their human forms, all the other players get Wrath"
date: or monster XP. So as any given player human(s) get stronger
recommended: the monsters of the other players get stronger. This keeps the players' monsters roughly scaled with players' human forms
hoursPlayed: and it means that people who are especially good at playing only humans or only monsters may be in for a dramatic uphill battle once they get out of being a human/monster for an extended time.\n\nAlso

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is a roguelike game that is being developed by the Australian team, PowerHoof. This game was put onto Steam's early access list in August 2014. The developers are very active with producing updates and content for the game, as you can see by their updated blog - http://www.powerhoof.com/

Whilst I try to steer clear of Early Access games, and especially reviewing them, I decided to break my trend and try this game out as it was one I have been following for a while now.

Crawl can be played single player, or with up to four people on local co-op. I have only played single player so far, so my review will be solely based on that.

One of the players will control the hero, and the others will be in control of ghosts. The ghost's aim is to kill the hero, they can do this by possessing traps in the randomly generated dungeon the hero is crawling through. Ghosts are also able to spawn into demons and monsters in various rooms.  The hero will gain experience points by killing monsters put before him, more experience means more health and more damage. The hero will also find gold, which can be used to purchase new weapons, items, potions and special abilities.  Once the ghost manages to kill a hero, they swap roles and you rinse and repeat. Monsters which kill the hero will be rewarded with Wrath points, these points can be used at the end of each level to level up the monsters to be able to do more damage and gain more powerful abilities.

The traps found throughout the dungeons can vary from bouncing spike walls, to bolt arrow turrets. All of them provide a sufficient threat for the hero, since they can't actually be destroyed, all the hero can do is escape to the next room. Unlike the monsters, where the hero has to clear the room before being able to move on.

Crawl uses a nicely presented pixel style art which has a nice charm to it. Whilst it is more pixelated than most games that use this style, it actually looks a lot better than most of them. It gives it a feel as if you are playing in an arcade, with the Metal Slug style character selection screen, and the health bars at the bottom for all the players. I really enjoyed the look of Crawl, even though it's using a style which is growing very thin in the PC market at the moment.

From what I have seen so far, there is no story behind any of the game, purely focuses on the gameplay elements.

To begin with, Crawl is a very hard game to get to grips with. There isn't an easily find-able help menu or tutorial, and you are kind of just left to figure it out on your own. Whilst this can be done after ten or fifteen minutes, it would of been nice to get a proper introduction to the game. Since I was playing on single player mode, and was up against the AI all the time, I managed to breeze through the levels with hardly any difficulty at all. When it comes to purchasing items from the shop, the AI just seemed to pick things at random, whether they are worse than what they currently had or not. Maybe this is something which can be fixed in up coming updates.  I would anticipate the multiplayer mode to be where a difficulty curve takes a large rise though.

All of the dungeons in Crawl are randomly generated, so I can't really say much about the level design, but what I can say is that all the rooms are still interesting to be in, they have a large selection of breakable objects, some of which will hold extra gold, there are normally one or two traps in each room for the ghosts to poses, and there are normally, two, if not three, summoning ports for the ghosts to take control of one of their minions or monsters.

There is a huge amount of replay-ability to be had with Crawl; I am about two hours into playing so far, and I am barely scratching the surface as to the amount of gameplay there is. Each time you finish a run, you unlock new weapons, items and abilities to use, making the next run you play completely different to the last.  I would absolutely love to see some sort of online multiplayer added to this game, limiting it to just local multiplayer seems like a silly idea to me, especially if you are putting your game on Steam. It could so easily be integrated with Steam's servers and made to be a fantastic online multiplayer experience.

I had no technical issues whilst playing the game. A controller is highly recommended, as most rogue-likes go, it is increasingly difficult to play these games on a keyboard.

To conclude, since Crawl is still an early access title, I am simply going to recommend it, but verging on the side of caution. Whilst the devs are still updating the game currently, early access games always run the risk of never being completed. However, the game has a low enough in price to allow you to take that risk with the knowledge that you are easily getting your money's worth as things stand at the moment. If/when this game gets a full release, it's easily going to be a game you'll keep installed ready to launch when you have friends over.


Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

http://store.steampowered.com/app/293780

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl: Antagonistic Cooperation

If you’ve never heard of Crawl, stop what you’re doing and run, don’t walk, to youtube and watch the trailer. It is the best trailer for any video game I have ever seen. Don’t worry I’ll wait.

No seriously, watch it.

If you have no idea what kind of a game Crawl is, let me tell you…

Crawl is a four player local co-op dungeon crawler. One player is the Human and the other three are the Monsters. Simple concept. Amazing execution.

You might be thinking, “One guy is the Human? Sucks for the other three!” Not really.

I’ve had the game since Early Access release (August, 6th 2014), and in that time I’ve learned this game is fun by yourself, but it shines when you have four living breathing people to play together. It is a lot like Super Smash Bros: great by yourself, but best with friends. And it’s completely possible to have a wonderful time never even playing as the Human. The Monsters are that interesting and fun.

As the trailer showed (seriously you should watch it), when a monster kills the Human their ‘Humanity’ is transferred to the killer. Just like how gold is awarded in DOTA, rage upon last hit stealing is also included, which ensures everyone is going to be the Human at least once per playthrough. And as the Human player(s) level up, everyone else gains ‘Vitae’ which is used to level up your Monsters, ensuring there is always a challenge.

In some cases, Human players will take an early lead and level up too quickly, causing the Monsters to scale up faster than the player can cope. Meaning at level 10, Humans might have a similar experience to a player at level 1 (they can still get their teeth kicked in with relative ease). There have been many cases in which I’ve skyrocketed to level 6 or 7 and suddenly I’m fighting all 2nd tier Monsters with starting gear. This usually ends how you would expect; weeping in the fetal position.

The only way to actually gain gold is to draw blood as a monster. Mechanically speaking, that means damaging and/or killing the Human. This creates a desire to play as both the Human and the Monsters. The only way to improve your Human is, ironically, to hurt and kill other Humans. Many times I have thought “I wish I had blood” whilst doing my best to prevent the others from taking my Humanity. In my experience, you almost always feel like you’re about to die when playing as the Human. And when playing as the Monsters, you’re working with your friends one minute and then actively working against them the next. The fluid nature of the cooperation in this game is amazing. There is nothing else like it.

The main goal of the game is for the Human player to reach level 10 as quickly as possible, find the Eldritch Stones, and challenge the boss. If they win, they win! If they lose? They have to continue further into the dungeon with about 1/10th of their HP. After a total of three loses, the current Human loses the game. They’re ‘CONSUMED FOREVER,’ and the game deletes their account.

Dark Souls would be proud.

There is never a dull moment when playing Crawl. Whether you’re the Monsters or the Human, there is always pressure. If you wait too long, the Spirits will collect ectoplasm and summon blobs on you. There’s nothing worse than fighting tooth and nail to get through a room only to have all of your buddies summon nine blobs to finish you off.

Trying to fight three other players who are working together to kill you but against each other to kill you first… is very hectic. And with so much happening on screen, it can be difficult to keep track of who and where you are. For the most part, it isn’t too hard to parse your position. It’s definitely harder to find yourself after you’ve lost track than it is to lose track in the first place. Perhaps something like an aura with your color could be added?

Losing yourself aside, Crawl has an incredible lo-fi feel, while still letting you know it’s a modern game. The sprites are evocative of older games, yet they still feel fresh, new, and lively. The animation is fluid. The colors are deep and have good contrast (Thanks to the v0.3 Plague Mushroom update, released 1/15/15). Seriously, this is some of the best pixel art I’ve experienced.

Also the music is superb. That’s all I really have to say. It’s great.

Overall, Crawl is an exceptional game with great gameplay, amazing art, and outstanding music. It’s simply dripping with flavor. Powerhoof managed to cram so much style into a “simple” game. It is refreshing, fun, and one of the best $10 games I’ve ever had the privilege of purchasing.

Buy it and play it with all of your friends.

The dudes over at Powerhoof are going places. They have created such a great game and deserve more recognition.

And, seriously, that trailer was amazing.

Like this review? Check out http://100hoursave.wordpress.com/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is a unique experience that can only be described with one word. Awesome.
This dungeon crawling masterpiece is incredibly fun to play. I love playing it so much. Here's why:
-Radomized Dungeons: Each time you play the game, you get something different. Even the textures on the wall are different each run.
-Wide Variety of Weapons: There are lots of different weapons to choose from, and not all of them are the same. There are heavy melee, light melee, ranged weapons, and magic weapons as well as various spells/abilities that can be aquired during a run.
-Play as the Monsters: This game is meant for 2-4 players (I suggest 4 even if 3 are bots), 1 player is the hero while the other 3 are ghosts who can become monsters to try to kill the hero and take his place. It adds a unique feel to this game.
-Multiplayer Mayhem: This game really is meant to be played by 4 people (even if can be played by 1), with 4 people this game becomes an all out brawl to become the hero and beat the boss to clear the game. It is an unforgettable experience to gather some friends and just play this game.
Crawl is an amazing game and the devs should be really proud of themselves. I can tell that they put a lot of hard work and energy into making this game the best it can be. I really hope to see more content added to Crawl to make it an even better experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, so I've never done any review. Ever.

But this game deserves it. So let's get started.

First of all, what is Crawl?
Like the name suggests, along with the pictures, you might understand that it's your usual dungeon crawler. But it isn't.
It IS a dungeon crawler. But not in the likes of Diablo or Torchlight. It's more of a skilled-hack 'n' slash-dungeon crawler.
And TBH, as a fan of dungeon crawlers, this is the best one I've ever seen.

I might also add that I may have a little bias about it because of the god damned amazing music/teaser trailer. But I digress.

As I've said before, it's not your usual dungeon crawler. And there's also another reason because of that. It's not open world and it's not story driven. It's an arcade game.

And it does it really well. The game, as you may already know if you're reading this review because you want to be sure that the game is nice, is a local co-op/versus game.

But Baron! I don't have any friends! I'm a god damned loner!"

Well they added some bots which you can play against for "practice while you're waiting for your friends". And they're also going to add multiplayer in the near future. So that's good. Because I'm also a loner.

How's the gameplay?
It's good

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing 4 player couch co-op game!

When I first bought the game things seemed really chaotic and disjointed, but after about 5 minutes in-game things started making a lot of sense: You're basically playing a modified version of playground-style Predator vs Prey. One person starts out as the hero and the other three players (or AI) are ghosts that can inhabit deadly traps to attack the hero, or stand on a pentagram and become a monster with special abilities.

The goal of the hero is to level up and beat the dungeon boss, while the goal of the ghosts are to collect ectoplasm to level up, kill the hero, take over his body and kill the boss. Along the way, you stumble upon shops where you can buy trinkets that give you buffs, or new weapons. Going deeper into the dungeon allows all players to level up their summonable monsters which evens the playing field between hero and ghost.

The first time I got to play this game with three other friends was when I realized that this game was truly worth the purchase and the risk of buying an early access game. I tend to stay away from EA games unless I see that they have true potential of becoming a complete game, and this one definitely has it. If you're on the fence about getting this game, take my advice and BUY IT! You won't be dissapointed.

The best local co-op game in my opinion. If you're looking for non-stop fun killing your friends and taking your throne as the ultimate friend, well this game is for you. Definitely worth the money you paid for this game.

You can play with someone using only mouse and keyboard. Other than that is through the use of controllers.
While you wait for your challengers, you can train against the bots and they are deemed quite powerful in the normal difficulty, how much more in the hard difficulty which is no mercy.

There are also deity challenges that really measures your capability against others. One of it is the Glub where you only stick to one monster type and weapon in which you cannot evolve nor change weapons. Are you up for the challenge?

I am keen and supportive to the development of the game because I am a huge fan of this game and to the team behind it. Updates take a while because it is only made by two people behind it but when they release it, it comes with a bang.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is an incredibly fun multiplayer dungeon crawler, where you take control of a hero, or monsters.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BTW6VWBZhT8
At the beginning, everyone selects what monster leader they'd like, which determines what monster minions they'll be able to use within the game. Once a game starts, one player is chosen to be the human hero. The other players start as ghosts, that can only affect the player through possessing traps around the dungeon, or spawning as a monster on a pentagram. All monsters have unique abilities.

If a monster kills the hero, they will become the hero themselves, and transform the previous hero into a monster. If the hero kills a monster, then they will gain xp, as well as give wrath" to the enemy ghosts. The ghosts can then use this to upgrade their monsters into evolutions with different abilities. This keeps the game balanced very well.
A hero can use collected gold to purchase new weapons

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very solid game for early access. and has an enormous amount of style and potential.  I do have a few complaints about the overall balancing however.

1. Defensive playstyles through monsters are ultimately more rewarding than aggresive playstyles, and camping is a big problem. (Atleast, in the 12 hours we've played collectively).

2. Because of this, some of the final monster evolutions are not worth evolving too (Im thinking of the slug, for example)

3. Part of the issue is because of all these defensive options you're given as monsters, it almost feels like online would just be overwhelmingly frustrating to deal with if it was implimented. If i wasn't sitting next to some friends playing this game, i'd probably have ragequit against the defensive playstyles in an online setting playing against people who i didn't know. (This is just personal prefernce however, and im sure online would still be an amazing adition for the community and players of this game)

If the dev's were able to find a way to combat this while not completely destroying the ranged characters playstyle, it'd be much more rewarding to play as a monster, and maybe not feel like such a scumbag to your friends all the time.

Negatives aside, this is still a blast to play, and leads to many hilarious moments. May lead to some frustrations, but ultimately is one of the most entertaining Couch co-op games i've played.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Below you'll find a written and video impression of the game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e_2zCZm3sLY
Crawl takes the idea of dungeon crawling to a competitive level. The game features an unique A-symmetrical competitive design where it's a hero against a team of ghouls. Though the ghouls can not directly harm the hero, they can spawn mobs, turn into greater mobs, and take control of traps to hinder the hero's progress. Though the ghouls have the common goal of killing the player, they are still in competition with each other to land the killing blow. To break it down, it's an XP race, and you can't gain XP unless you are the hero, and you can only become the hero if your ghoul lands the killing blow. This dynamic presents some very interesting and unforeseen strategies.

The game's art, music, and sound design are all top-notch, and worthy of praise. The pixel art is detailed and well animated, while the music and sound design is distinctly 16 bit. Overall the game keeps to it's theme quite well, and it's certainly not too hard on the eyes.

Though the game features some very unique and interesting ideas, and top shelf presentation, it's not with out it's flaws. Currently, as of this impression, the game only features local multiplayer. For a game that is very multiplayer focused, this is a huge sin. Those who have people close at hand, Crawl is an easy recommendation, but if don't, then you have to consider your purchase more. I've played this solo and still enjoyed it greatly, but after a while, bots are bots, and once the gimmick of the unique mechanics is settled away, boredom can eventually set in. I can see how this is much more interesting with live people, unfortunately I never got to experience this very important aspect of the game due to it's lack of online.

Overall all Crawl is a very uniquely designed competitive game that is both engaging and beautiful. Even at it's current early state the game feels stable and finished". Any new updates from this point will feel more like extra content
date: than the game making up for obviously missing parts. This is a good thing :) It's just too bad about the lack of online. With out it It's not as easy of a recommendation as it deserves to be
hoursPlayed:
that will be rectified.

Pros:
- Uniquely designed competition / mechanics
- Great presentation
- Easy to understand

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent and unpretentious top down roguelike dungeon crawler that's over the top when it comes to fast paced extremely satisfying and gory gameplay. This game is especially good for when you want to sit down and have a quick instant fix of fast action, because matches mostly range between 20-45 minutes, and can even last longer depending on how much you want to level up before facing the boss.

The atmosphere is on point in terms of making you feel as if you're exploring a dank dark dungeon that's haunted by an ancient evil presence, the spirits that haunt you, follow you and possess traps and summon monsters only add to this feeling... there are some references to Lovecraft's work in the level names which is always a nice touch, the rooms and map layouts are randomly generated and every playthrough is different, but unlike many other games with randomly generated rooms you don't start noticing the same variation of a room being repeated until maybe 5 or so hours, there isn't an arbituary set pattern in which you experience rooms either, the only thing that's consistent is that each floor has one store (with each floor having randomly selected different items, making way for different character builds which further ensures each playthrough is unique), one portal that leads to the final boss and one exit that leads to the floor below.... anyway regardless, even if the room layouts aren't always unique... the map layouts are always unique, the repetition of rooms isn't something you're bothered by because you're too busy trying to get the final shot on the hero or you're the hero desperately trying to cling to every last inch of your humanity and you really become absorbed in the addictive gameplay... it's also worth mentioning that the developers are awesome dudes who are very responsive to the community, always respond positively to ideas, negative criticism, and are still constantly showcasing screenshots of different environments / room layouts that are in progress so you can expect to see much more variation in that department in the future, at the rate I see them posting screenshots of new room types, my point on rooms repeating themselves once or twice per match will probably be completely and utterly void by the time this game gets a release... it's also really fun to play single player even if it's designed for co op!

Recommended!

PS: I love the skeletons to death, whenever they laugh or use their ranged attacks where they throw a bone at you, I get a flashback of Evil Dead III: Army of Darkness where the skeleton says to Ash; I've got a bone to pick with you!" :P"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite being in Early Access, Crawl is one of the most unique, interesting, and promising games in the overdone and dry market of dungeon crawlers. And don't forget that updates are still coming, adding even more variety to an already good game.

Pros:
•Updates are often filled with a good amount of content, even if they are aren't very often.
•A base idea* that is becoming more common, but never done in this way.
•Different monster progression paths to follow.
•Unlockable paths, monsters, traps, and weapons.
•Variety of the above.
•Beautiful art style.
•AI to play against, if you have no friends like me :(

Cons:
•Environment has no variety, but they recently added a whole new environment and plan on adding more.
•Somewhat bland color palette, hopefully getting better with new environments.
•AI seems a little off, but not too much.

*The Idea of one monster VS 3 or 4 good players is being used in a few games, such as Evolve. In Crawl, there's one alternating player fighting a ton of monsters inhabited by 3 ghosts.

Overall, a great buy for you and your friends, but still does great for singleplayer. Despite the beautiful style, the environment is still relatively unvaried and bland. If you really want, wait until its out of Early Access if it bothers you that much, but other than that, it could easily be released today, albeit without as much content as it could have.
A solid 7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is an excellent four player local competitive game, with a well defined style and a lot of heart. You're four lost souls damned to wander an unholy dungeon, fighting to escape through exerting your will upon the frail flesh which happens to pass before you. As a spirit, you are ever at odds for when you inhabit the hero the other spirits seek to displace you, and when you are a spirit, you must be the one to strike the killing blow if you would escape. Once you've advanced your hero to a sufficient level, and subsequently discovered a portal, you can go through it to face a monstrosity which may end up inhabited by all your foes. Fail there, and return to the dungeon, until someone escapes, or you collectively fail too often.

If Crawl has a flaw, and you do not agree that the flaws are at times inherent to the beauty of a piece, it is that the game loop is secured around four players. If you do not have four people, you will need to fill the remaining slots with A.I. which - while quite capable - is not nearly as unpredictable and thus exciting as a human player.

Purchase a copy, invite three of your friends, and prepare to writhe - no - crawl your way back to the living.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is an enormously entertaining game.  The interesting mix of so many elements is immensely entertaining.  Crawl is a retro themed, but modern take of a dungeon crawling mix of assymetrical multiplayer with co-op and campaign elements among many other great elements.  This game is the perfect combination of game elements that just becomes... well, perfection.  I started gaming years ago and have played games of practicaly any kind, but this game is somewhere in my top 3 favorite games of all time!  It is perfection!

Now, time to address negative reviews.  All negative reviews of this game either complain about the lack of online multiplayer or lack of content in the Early Access version at the time they typed up the review.  Since the writing of those reviews at the early Early Access of the game, the game has gained a ton of more flesh to it.  It is full of content and exciting gameplay and there are still updates to come because this amazing game is still in Early Access.  Online play has not yet been implemented so it can be hard to find the full 4 player game it was meant for, however, at the time of me typing this review I have a 19 hours of gameplay.  At least 12 of which have been me with no other players and just a full roster of bots and I still found this game amazingly entertaining.

Overall, this game is one of the best games of all time and deserves to be on a top 10 list of games of all time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A superb party game with great animation.
Multiplayer Crawl is amazing fun. You can play it against bots and they work great but multiplayer is really where it's at. It feels like arcade games used to back in the golden age of arcade games.

It makes a great party game, but take note that the multiplayer is local only (at least for now) and you will need joypads, ideally.
One player can use the keyboard but you can't aim precisely using it. You can use this to handicap a player if they're winning too often though, or turn off precise aiming for everyone if you like. You can even use a mouse as a controller if you're desperate.

Powerhoof have also added a 'taunt your god' option, to properly handicap individual players in a variety of ways, fixing the one gripe I did have about the game.

One player at a time has human form and all the other players are ghosts that gang up and try to kill them with monsters and traps. Get the killing blow on the human player and you take human form instead! The human player advances through the dungeon to attempt to kill the boss and win.

The animations are superb, the music is great, the controls are tight and responsive and the combat is smooth and impactful. Even in Early Access the game has a lot of variety, there are a ton of weapons, items, potions, abilities and monsters.

Also the trailers are great, and the main trailer gives a nice overview of the game if you're about to start up a game with new players.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is an excellent couch mulitplayer title. It's gameplay is easy for anyone to pick up and can be enjoyed in short bursts or long playthroughs.

While it does feature bots and a Challenge singleplayer mode it is better enjoyed with friends. The two button controls make it easy to have two players with just the keyboard and mouse, one player using each, without being cramped on the keyboard.

It has a variety of procedurally generated rooms, filled with traps, upgradable monsters and there are many secrets and mysteries to be found (one worthy of Gaben himself...).

Seriously, stop reading this review and get it when it's cheap! It's guarenteed to be a hit with you and your friends.

The only downside is that at the time of this review it does not have online multiplayer, but it's still in early access so that and many other features are bound to be introduced soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is seriously awesome. The developers are very active in creating more and more content, and it’s already packed full of coolness. While the art is pixilated, the movement does not have an “old” feel to it, but a smooth fast paced action feel. The game changes each time you play in regards to maps and which enemy characters each person chooses, and the player choices during the game. It seriously keeps things fresh.

PROS:
* Insanely fun game play
* Original concepts with a 1 VS 3 game of dungeons and dragons where it’s 1 hero against 3 dungeon masters
* Controller Support for 4 players local
* Fast paced action that feels fresh each time due to the roguelike aspects of each level
* You can choose how you progress as an anti-hero depending on which enemy path you choose to use each game
* Great balancing mechanics that can bring an underdog back into the fray where no one feels as if there is no hope

CONS:
* No save function - you may need a break after an hour of button mashing
* No online multiplayer (yet?)
* Bots are easy to anticipate since their strategy is pretty linear

This game, even in Early Access, is an absolute BUY NOW.
If you have a friend who can come over to play, you will be more than happy with this game and it will become a “go to” in your Steam Library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It’s been a long time coming, and it’s finally here.

In the caverns beneath Steam, all turn to CRAWL.

I present to you . . . my review of CRAWL.

For time untold I had drifted, bored and alone.

But now I watched as a simple developer once again trod the Early Access halls, developing a game that must be played.

I took possession of debit cards and PayPal sprung at my command, and when my Library increased a number by one, I could rise for a time as a player of a dungeon CRAWLer.

I summon my 360 controller and my gaming headset with a microphone for multiplayer. I wore them for leisure and abuse their usage and flung them at this game. Again and again, the bots cut me down! And I was tickled to see a trace of smugness in their eyes.

Did they think I would just play with bots down here?

Play with 3 Human Players!

The others flanked with analogs, mice, and keyboards, and bled bots of their purpose. They were soon to die, these puppets of artificiality. But when will Powerhoof deliver the killing blow? If they could slay them now, the game would be reborn . . . filled with humans.

Kill your friends and smile about it.

And as time went on, they fell! Purpose poured from their corpses and filled CRAWL to the brim and flashed praise and anticipation of multiplayer and flared my excitement, reborn.

Go to the forums; post your opinions and suggestions

Powerhoof was pleased with the suggestions we have given and rewarded us with content and updates. Taking these, I lobbied with a friend, for fun, excitement . . . and the urge to kill.

Only one gets out alive after all

With new vicious tools, I butchered friend after friend, growing ever delightful, but my friends grew also, and I could seldom hold my Humanity for long. Avatars were shredded underfoot as we fought for our prize: that one fading spark of opportunity.

We seized it!

We lost it!

We took it and we fled!

For Humanity alone held the difference. And stealing that prize, I hurled viscous blades and teeth and flame—

To a room most strange and very boss-like.

The eldritch stones split a ragged hole in the air, a gateway to the Final Boss above.

And winning . . . if you dare take 1 of 3 chances behind.

ahem, ahem

Okay, now that that’s over with. The results are here:

Graphics: Retro, not a bad thing really. It worked well here.

Sound: Retro and somewhat repetitive. Like the olden games betwixt the 80s and 90s.

Gameplay: Chaotic, but fun. Really fun. Future updates will have to require an indicator to keep track of your player’s location on the screen, though; colors alone are insufficient for something this fast-paced.

Replay Value: Oh eff the hell YESSSSSSS!

Verdict: A great buy for playing with friends and ganging up on each other. Also hope to play with strangers in multiplayer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great! I'll try to avoid giving out the same details as everyone else, but the praise is well-deserved, this game does a ton of things right! Now, since all the peeps below me have given the game the good stuff, I'll say all the bad stuff I have come across.
Firstly, the rooms look nice, they really do, but they all look the same, their shapes are different, and that does determine life or death in circumstances, but still, change it up a bit please. Secondly, the game could use some balancing, the starting human starts off at  major disadvantage to the monsters when they inevitably fall and become a monster, they're a super-weak monster (this is an early access, so this'll be fixed sooner or later.). The controls are also less fit for a keyboard as you can only aim in 4 directions, this can be fixed with a controller, but not all of us have those, and it often makes the game a tad more difficult when aiming. The boss also has an unskippable cutscene which after a while made the boss look kind of...Cute, in a derpy fashion...(IGNORE THAT.).
Besides the above, this game is a great example of early-access done right, and its dev's are fun guys. I highly suggest you get it if you have friends locally near you, if not, it may not be the best, but you can play with bots, who are pretty smart, and can become stupid if you turn down the difficulty.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCrawl is a great game I give it 4 out of 5 stars for the state its in as of 08/07/2015 and let me tell you why. Its pretty much like its not in early access. What I like about the game is that there are a lot of possibilities in the battle of who is to win. I like how there are only three chances you get to win the game. With that being said, anyone over the level of 10 could go for it when they reach the shrine. As of right now there are two bosses you can either be or fight which is randomly chosen for you when you activate the shrines. Either you or the other 3 players (depending on who activates the shrine) become part of the three parts of the boss, and you have to try to defeat the boss while the others use the boss to defeat you. Anyone can fail twice fighting the boss battles. The third time whoever fails will ultimately lose the game and the other players win in a first, second, third basis.(The loser being 4th) I also like the dynamic of there is one hero and the others are ghosts vying for the life of the hero and use forms of monsters to try to steal the life of the hero and become him. All an all this is a great game and I cannot wait for the full version. What I would like to see in the full version is a database for all that you unlock like a lore, just like Risk Of Rain. And also I really hope and pray they create multiplayer because that would make it 5 stars in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everyone needs to play this game. Even though it is in early access, it has very little bugs. ( so little I haven't spotted one)

The main goal is to level up to ten and defeat the boss at the end. Sounds simple until you have a three friends over with the same goal.

This game is fun alone and with your friends. The fighting is simple and easy to use. ( for both ghosts and humans) The game is also very balanced. You also unlock more items for your next round. I haven't unlocked everything yet, but everytime I do unlock something (you unlock at least one thing every game) I want to see it and test it out. This game has a ton of items to choose from. Making it very easy to fit your play style. One more thing I love is the gods" you can pick from. The gods is like your class for your hero. They give you three monsters and a passive to help your ghost or hero. In the end of every level you can level up your monsters.

In the end

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the best games of 2014. A wonder take on king of the hill, one player is the adventurer delving a dungeon, the other three players are ghosts that possess creatures of the darkness and control traps, all vying to be the one to land the killing blow on the adventurer to steal his humanity. Die, kill, die again, try and take back your humanity and then slay the boss monster guarding the exit. It's a hell of a romp for couch gaming.

Con if you don't have friends that will come over and game: no online at present. The local multiplayer aspect adds a great deal to the experience.

The latest update for 9/26 added new monsters, deities, and balance changes. Scorpion OP, demon lord sucks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Officially one of my go-to games when I have friends over. We must have played 5 rounds in a row on the night I installed it. The rounds are fairly short (~30min) and there's always something for every player to do, be it collecting slime, attacking, haunting traps, or just staying alive.
I'm a huge fan of local co op games, and as such, have 4 wireless controllers, so the lack of online multiplayer isn't an issue for me. These games are just much more fun when you're in the same room as your friends.

P3: *dies* Nooooo!"
P1:  "WHO GOT THAT LAST HIT? WAS IT M- *Humanity Restored* WHAAAA? DAMMIT."
P2: *smug smile*

Can't see defeat in your enemies eyes online...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short version:
Get it if you have 1 to 3 friends, (so, a total of 4 peeps,) that love playing new types of games on a couch.

Longer version:
Couch Conflict games are great but tend to fall into a very small selection of catagories.
A large number are 1 screen platformers.
Another swathe are 1 screen asteroids" based twin stick shooters.
Within these 2 large pools there are some stellar gems
recommended: a few minor tweaks and innovations and a lot of "others" that don't really distinguish them selves well.\nFor the most part
hoursPlayed: if you have a handful of entries from these groups in your library
voteText:
you'll have the basics covered and dipping back in too the pools probably won't net you anything wonderfully different.

So it's always exciting when clever people come up with something that feel radically different with out over complicating what you seek out from these experiances.
Nighogg is a great example of this idea
helpfulPercent: and if you're looking at Crawl as a multiplayer couch gamer
votesHelpful: you probably already know about the joys of that.\n\nWhat Crawl offers is different again... and does take a minute more to absorb
votesTotal: but after that you will be drinking in a game that takes the head to head nature of this genre and mixes in a brilliant and ever changing landscape of all vs 1 and and great "begining-middle-end" arc in each session.\n\nIf you have your basic couch conflict games covered
votesFunny:
Get Nidhogg and get this and you'll have a great little menu to pick from.

Nighog for instantly accessable gaming at snack like speed.
Twin stick arenas and 1 screen platformers for experiances with a hair more length and variable substance.
Crawl for a solid hunk of entertainment that still leaves room for multiple sessions.

(Oh and Mount your friends for dessert... because it's fruity and lite) :D

"

Overall, I give this game a perfect 10.

A 'bloody' brilliant couch co-op game that deserves to be in your steam library!

Being a beat 'em up and an (RPG?) it feels great with each impact of your sword/monster attack; and having the hero die from one of your attacks is hilariously satisfying.

The game features heaps of unlockables and sets of various monsters each being unique in their own way. There are many items that can assist your hero and sometimes monsters!

the music if fun (as chiptunes are pretty brilliant).

I highly recommend getting this game if you have friends (If you don't, still get the game as it includes bots)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played this game ever since it came out. I invited some friends over, and we had a blast screwing each other over, and continue to to this day. The game has come so far, starting with just 3 evolutionary trees and a handful of monsters, to 10+ trees, 40 monsters, and a gigantic variety of monster-slaying weaponry to fend off your impending doom. If you're looking for a fun party game with an arcadey, rpg feel, this is the game for you. If I had the opportuntiy to buy this game again, I would gladly do so,

I do have a few minor complaints -- you almost need controllers to have the best experience. Playing with the keyboard or mouse is sufficient, but controllers provide a more fuild playstyle. Other than that, the only other problem I have is that some evolutionary trees seem to be better than others, but that really depends on your proficiency with certain monsters.

As of when this review was written, there are only two bosses, but the ghosts work together inside of one boss to thwart the player. There is a hydra, with three heads -- fire, ice, and poison -- and a kranken that fires an enormous laser whilist trapping the hero in bubbles and spewing pink acid. Nothing is more satisfying than killing the boss on your ast try, with 1 health remaining... or, killing the hero at the very last second.

Having all 4 players isn't a necesity, but does provide a unique experience. Colluding with your friends to utterly destroy the human is such a fun feeling. If you don' have 4 friends immediately around, playing vs another friend is a challenge that tests your ability to fully utilize your monsters and/or hero abilities and skills. On the off-chance you have exactly 0 people to play with, you can always fight with the AI on varrying difficulty levels.

10/10, would kill friends over and over again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is already one of the best couch (semi-)coop games you can get imo, even though it’s in early access. The game offers a whole new experience: in-game friends turn to enemies and the other way round.
Also it never felt like a beta, it seemed very well thought-out from the get-go and now they are adding new content and balance it a bit more, a flagship early access game if you ask me.

At our first session we’ve played the game 6 hours straight without noticing the time going by. It is definitely already one of the best invested 10€ ever.

The graphics are great, if you like pixel art and the sound/music really fit the game well.

But before you buy it, you have got to have at least 2 friends who are willing to play it with you (offline ofc). And I’m saying this, because the graphics really put off some people and the start of the game can be a little hard, because eventhough the game uses only to buttons aside from the stick, it can really get confusing. So I’d suggest you’d play it with “gamers”. But if your friends are hooked they are hooked for good and will be as excited about the game as I am.
Aside from that It’s the most fun I’ve had with a game in a long time. I’ve played it 13h by now and it would have been much longer if I had more people to play it with.

Go try it out! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An Absolutely outstanding game.

I walked into this game being a little skeptical of the promise and ambition the the trailer highlighted, but I was so, so plesently surprised.

unlike most indie games still in alpha this game has an amazing level of polish to it. After several hours of playing I have not once experienced a single crash or significant bug. The fighting is also incredibly balanced and the player and monsters never feel ridiculously powerful or impossible to kill. you never die from a cheap shot and every bit of damage you take feels like you could have avoided it. it has a very Dark-Souls-Esk feel to the combat, its fast, fluid, responsive and satisfying and you never feel punished for dying.

Additionally, if you have no buddies to play with the, AI is superb, acting much like a human does in how it moves, fights and decides to buy items (pausing for a brief moment to think). having the choice to alter the amount of players (from 2 to 4) is great and acts as  a subtle way of modifing the difficulty in addition to the AI also has a difficulty modifyer.

controllers also have complete compatability, very literally plug and play. either it be a 360 or ps3. (I cannot confirm for other controllers, but it seems to be the case)

but when you have 4 controllers, the computer hooked up to the big screen and a few beers around, this game absolutely shines. even in alpha this game is honestly brilliant.


BUGS
These are the only bugs that I have noticed thus far (and they are pretty minor ones at that).

1. as a ghost you can fly around the map collecting ectoplasm. when you collect enough you can spawn upwards of 3 slimes to enter the field at any time. they are weak, but can certainly be an effective distraction, causing surprising damage if not delt with.

There appears to be a spawning bug, you can place them anywhere on the field  however placing them too close to a wall or corner will result in them getting stuck and unable to move. This is no problem as they are easily cleaned up and the game can continoue, but this will probably be quite easily fixed in later versions.


2. The AI. while acting pretty reasonable most of the time and are certainly a worthy challenge (I am yet to win a watch against simply 2 AI on normal, I cant imagine what 3 on hard would be like).

they do, ever so rarely get a little confused if there is alot of gunk on the floor. As they try to avoid it they end up running over it multiple times and take significant amount of damage figuring out how to behave (but they do snap out of it eventually) . yet, so far, this has only happened maybe 2-3 times in the many matches I have played and only seem to last for that room. its a rare occurance and will probably be patched at a later date.


but apart from that.....nothing of mention, the game is very well polished. very easily worth the asking price.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've really liked this game. So far I've been playing it for about an hour and here are some of my first impressions:

Gameplay: The gameplay itself is very sleek and smooth. Crawl resembles that of a button mashing arcade figher, which isn't a bad thing. There are two buttons you use to attack (primary and special) which just feels very satisfying. The concept itself is original as well, and that's something I haven't seen in quite a while. It's almost like a multiplayer dungeon crawler King of the Hill RPG.

You battle your friends who are attemtping to kill you in order to revive themselves as humans and collect randomized dungeon loot along the way. If you or any of your friends finish off the human, they revive and then have their shot at completing the level. As the ghost characters, you take control of items and can summon monsters which you can evolve. At a certain point along the way you gain enough experience to fight the boss battle. Admittedly, the boss battle did come a little quickly and I had beaten the game before I knew it. However I noticed I unlocked a few items, so I know that coupled with the randomly generated levels means replayability is implied.

Art Style: I'm also a fan of this art style which is what first caught my eye. The animations are smooth and the characters are well drawn. I've never been the type to complain about pixel art as if it were an excuse to real art"; it looks great. The only issue is I find myself backing away from the monitor to get the full view of some text which is otherwise a little difficult to read from up close.

Music: About what you would expect
date: pretty catchy but has a few points where it appears to stutter.\n\nThis game is in early stages
recommended: and it looks promising. So if it's good now
hoursPlayed:
it can only get better.
It's only $10 right now so there's really nothing to lose by giving this a try.

I suppose the only thing I'd like to see a network multiplayer. And I understand the naivity of most people who make that statement and don't understand that networking isn't an easy task
voteText: but I could see this game being a blast at LAN parties and with friends who don't want to crowd around one screen or use mutliple controllers."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Platform: Ubuntu 14.04 with mid-high specs (see profile for details). Runs absolutely perfectly, with brilliant gamepad support using steamos-dkms xpad drivers.

I have a soft spot for local multiplayer, and so I tend to add to basket as soon as I see a game tagged in this way. This review starts by saying that Crawl is potentially one of the best local multiplayer games I've played for a while.

I played this game last night with my sister and parents (3 gamepads and myself, the unfortunate soul with the keyboard). I know we'll play again tonight, its that kind of game. Each time you play it begins like this, someone starts up the game, everyone taps their respective controller and occupies a slot, which the game cutely refers to as inserting a coin. You enter a 3 letter name, or choose a previously used one. Then you select a deity to worship (as of writing this review there are 3 deities; two instantly available and 1 unlockable). Your choice of deity decides what sort of beasts you can manifest yourself as to hinder the current hero. The game begins.

The current hero is selected randomly from the up-to-4 players, and attempts to crawl through the dungeon as far as possible, amassing gold, buying new items and buffs. All the while, the non-hero players attempt to kill the hero by either manifesting as monsters by activating pentagrams that are one the floor of some rooms, going-poltergeist" and possessing traps or turrets
date: or summoning slimes that they can stockpile by collecting dust. The non-hero player that kills the hero player gets to continue where the previous hero player left off
recommended: albeit without his buffs and items
hoursPlayed: these have to be collected individually. The object of the game
voteText: which you can only progress towards during your time as the hero
helpfulPercent: is to reach at least level ten so that you can open the boss portal
votesHelpful: and defeat the boss. Aside from this the game has intervals everytime a player descends to a lower floor. During these intervals players receive vitae points for everytime an opposing player levelled up on the previous floor. They can use these points to evolve their selection of beasts
votesTotal: making them stronger and a greater threat to opposing heroes.\n\nWhy I like it so muchThe game offers a simple but very replayable mechanic. The non-hero players work together to try and kill the current hero
votesFunny: but ultimately want to beat the others to land the final blow and secure precious flesh-and-blood hero time. The current hero works to improve their items
commentsCount: spells and buffs so that they can fight off opposing players for longer. The struggle is fast paced
column16: skillful and very fun. After level 10 players have the chance to nab the winner's position by choosing to fight the boss
column17: but they only get so many chances
column18: otherwise they finish last. As more bosses are implemented into the game
column19:
the risk of entering the boss portal will become even more interesting; what if its a boss you don't like and you only have one chance left? Maybe you should level further? But what if one of your opponents goes through?

So so fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is possibly the single most fun game that I've played locally with 3 other people, and I've had a PS2/3 set up for it in my room for years, specifically for that purpose.

The combat is fast paced, brief and exciting, the light RPG elements have your choices affect the game significantly yet don't bog gameplay down because they're nice and simple, the art and animations are ( in my opinion at least ) gorgeous and delightfully crisp, and the sound design perfectly rounds out the frantic action, as well as the parts inbetween.

If you've got a couple of controllers and can get some people around a monitor, you would be hugely wronging yourself and your friends to not have this as one of your choices for the night. It really is amazingly fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gather up your friends, your controllers and some beers, and throw them all into a sack to carry with you, because you're going to want to play this all the time.

Don't want to gather 'round your hardcore gaming rig? Got a crappy laptop lying around? There's a chance it might be able to run Crawl. The system requirements are miniscule.

This is a very polished game, even at this early stage, and I simply cannot wait to see what Powerhoof does with it leading up to the full release.

Bonus points: the devs are really cool blokes, and they'll talk to you! Tell them what you think of their game, make suggestions. They genuinely want your feedback.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nExplosively good. The kind of experience that makes you want to arrange an in-person handshake. The gameplay is moment to moment satisfaction: your attacks make big loud noises whenever you smack a foe around, making the whole experience incredibly active. Not to mention the thrill of negotiating when to dodge, when to attack, what monster to take out first and what traps you THINK you can jump over. And all the while, big bright numbers are popping up whenever you score a hit, level up, collect gold, etc. The music builds and travels around you in a way that makes you feel like you're traveling further and further into something dangerous. Unlockables always make you want to play a second match, and there is an amazing amount of variety here for just ten dollars. All of the monsters and their evolution chains will bring a whole new slant to the way you fight, with some creatures bringing straight-up entirely NEW mechanics to gameplay that are exclusive to them. There's only one monster that can summon low level zombies. Only one monster that can heal itself and other monsters. Only one monster that can summon a gust of wind to move the hero into the path of a trap. Only one monster whose eye can be used as a weapon after you kill it! Bottom line, when love is behind the making of a game, you can tell right away. And the result is bombastically fun. Mighty fine balance that gives advantages to both being the ghost and being the hero, with both roles always presenting opportunities that will permanently better a player's position. The final boss is gorgeous and puts up a fight that will make you chomp your lip and raise your fist. This whole game will make you chomp your lip and raise your fist. Pummel-loving gameplay with an AD&D monstrous manual vibe that will make you smile. Would reccomend

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After a couple hours of gameplay, this is easily one of the most addicting games I've ever played. It's a fairly simple dungeon-crawler, yet it is very enjoyable. Very old-school, which is something I appreciate. In each round there are 4 players. Of these players, 3 are ghosts and 1 is a human. As a ghost, the objective is to work together with the other ghosts to slay the human. This can be done by turning into enemies, activating traps, and summoning blobs. When a human dies, the ghost who landed the killing blow then becomes the human. The goal is to stay human long enough to become level 10, after which you must find a portal and defeat a boss.

Pros and Cons:
+ Simple to learn, yet hard to master
+ Very addictive
+ Great multiplayer
+ Nonstop action, monster or human
+ Well-balanced mechanics (monster strength, health, etc.)
+ Old-school, classic video game feeling
+ Well randomized, even with small details
+ Lots of weapons
+ BE THE MONSTER
- No online multiplayer
- Only 2 bosses

As you can see, I have few complaints about the game. Overall, it is a well-made and very enjoyable game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted this game as soon as I saw the trailers, and I wasn't disappointed. In fact, I've played it everyday since I got it. It's a fast-paced game with great music, atmosphere, gameplay, and a lot of challenge without too steep a curve. I have only played with AI so far, and I still have a lot of fun. They feel like proper opponents, and help set the illusion that you're playing with people.

I first used keyboard controls. They're alright; I wouldn't advise you slouch or curl up while playing though, as there's a lot of rapid button-pushing involved and that'll make your hands cramp up very quickly. I now use an iBuffalo Classic USB gamepad; the same goes for it, although that might just be because it's a new gadget and hasn't been broken in yet. Both control sets work great! Word to the wise, though: As of now, you can't adjust the gamepad controls in the main menu; you have to start a game and then use the controls menu that appears immediately after.

The developers are still working out the kinks, I imagine, and they're adding new content all the time. The brief story-like introductions have some great variety to them, and there's nothing more awesome than going through all the new monsters, weapons, and items you unlock after every game. I have no complaints!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is a fun and new take on the classic dungeon crawler. However, instead of having a party of heroes, venturing into a dusty pit of doom, you have one hero and a party of evil ghosts, trying to kill him and thus take his place as the hero. The version I've played just before the early access started, had three evil gods to worship, each with his own set of horrible upgradeable monsters + tons of magic items for the hero to invest in, including madness inducing swords. And there's more to come!

If you love playing with a bunch of friends, this game gets my highest recommendation, even with the content at Early Access release. It's hours of fun for the price and the originality of the gameplay together with the charming blocky art style has already made this one of my favourite local multiplayer games on Steam.

Yeah this is a great party game that I look forward to having four player couch matches with. I watched several LetsPlay videos, which helped me write this review. Single player is fun, but overall don't pick it up unless you plan on having friends over for multiplayer.

Pros:

+Great take on having friends compete in a roguelike
+Devs seem to be still adding stuff

Cons:
-No online multiplayer
-Pixel art is great, but sometimes it can get a bit too abstract, which it borders on here

Overall, I think this is a fun game. Wait for a sale and its even better.

Early Access Review

This game is a gem of local co-op fun and chaos.

I took about 30-40 minutes per game with 2 humans and 1-2 AI players, and the game pacing felt about right. Crawl itself has a crazy simple design, looks and feels like an old arcade game (only 2 buttons, and one stick) I played with a controller and loved it (haven't yet tried the mouse). As simple as it was on paper, playing the hero took some work (monsters actually felt more responsive and intuitive, controllwise, than the hero), aiming ranged weapons took finesse, and missing a special or crucial attack because the target was moving around was heartbreaking, but  each time I moved to deny either my friend or the AI my precious humanity was a moment of absolute triumph. The cutscenes between hero death and the new hero entering the game gave the unfortunate loser a chance to exclaim thier losses, while the winner exclaimed thier victory.

The Games basic premise is refreshing, with 4 players all competeing for the chance to be a hero and defeat the boss. The switch off between being the hero, a monster, a trap and a ghost was enjoyable. Best moment was when I realized that the final boss was also controlled by the ghosts, and I took great pleasure in shooting my friend with a simple, but really enjoyable array of attacks. The ghosts will need to work together to take down the hero, because although they outnumber him, most of the time the hero has more health, and often does more damage (depending on monster level), when an AI hero battle began my friend and I would quickly talk strategy and each try to exploit the hero's predicament in order to land the final blow ourselves.

The chaotic and quick pace that ensued was enjoyed by all, and even though we didn't win the match, simply playing the game was enjoyable.  Finaly, after finishing the match we got to see the new items we unlocked for our next game, I can't wait to try and find them all.

For an early access game feels both polished, and nuanced.

8.9/10, can't wait to see what this game becomes!

Just bought this today after following the game in its development and boy does this game gives you the RUSH!

All the reviews you have been reading are true!

Controls are smooth and the attacks available are enough although soon you realize the action is not just button smash instead you need to plan your attacks and dodge / other special abilities you unlock to survive! :D

Action is heavy and you need to be quick on your feet to anticipate the enemy!

Played with bots now and 'normal' level is quite tough hope I can survive the 'hard' level :P

I have only played for around 25 minutes and I am already a fan!

This game has huge potential in the future with more additional contents and stuff do which will broaden the game mechanics such as different game modes and more stuff to unlock and explore!

With online multiplayer promised in the future this game is a piece of gold....


PROS:

+Varied Enemy who can be further be evolved with unique evolution trees! Sweet!
+Competitive Multiplayer, at no time do you feel that someone is winning through button smashing, you die because you suck...
+Loot is in form of XP and Blood (for ghosts) which can be traded with the blacksmith to buy higher level gear!
+Balanced mechanics (yet) although I dont feel balance will be an issue as the developers are hard against imbaness....
+Random Level Generation
+Bot AI
+Sweet Retro Graphics

CONS:

-Lack of Content at present there is only 1 boss and limited Gods(used for enemy set choice) to start with but this is an early access wait until they add more ;)
-Lack of more stuff / goals / game modes but at this point also gives you a focus, however in the long run I feel more varierty and goals will help enrich the experience and replaybility

Thanks for reading!

Early Access Review

Every once in a while, a game comes along that I get obsessed with. I found out about this game while it was still in development in greenlight and I've been hyped about it's release ever since. If their magnificent trailer doesn't sell you on how awesome it is, let me attest that this game is fantastic.

I don't advise buying early access games unless they are fun as-is. And this certainly meets that requirement! It is one of the most fun local multiplayer games that I've played since before I became a computer gamer.

This does NOT have online multiplayer. As the devs have said, if this a requirement for you just wait for more information. If not, it's a worthwhile purchase.

Early Access Review\n\nAwesome game with a pretty unique concept. It's a blast to play with friends and very easy to pick up and play, yet has a ton of replay value. Bought it on a whim because three friends and I were bored and we were hooked instantly and played nonstop for the next 4 hours. Seems super polished, even in early access and the devs obviously put a lot of love into it. The only downside I could see would be that it probably isn't something you would want to play alone, though it IS possible by turning on bots. The game was made for local multiplayer and it does an amazing job of fitting the role.

Early Access Review

Crawl  delivers just what it promises: A local multiplayer crawler type game with superb art and a great style and feel to it. From what little I have played of it I would definitely recommend it.
The game is well balanced, with one player taking on the role of hero, while the other three play as the ghastly dwellers of the dungeon, aiming to defeat the hero for their own benefit and to regain their mundane form.
In terms of combat the game flows very well, loot and different weapons can be aquired throughout the dungeon, and can be unlocked as you progress. There are different active abilities that the hero can preform, all from AoE damage to your more typical combat rolls. There are also plenty of different monsters with varied playstyles, tactics and various evolutions for the opposing players to control. The spirits can also possess various traps with different effects throughout the dungeon.
As it is only in early access, I can't wait to see this game developed even further in the future with even more content.

Early Access Review

It looks at tad simple at first, but after playing even one game the player will soon realise just how deep everything in this game really is. The combat, the evolution system, the bosses and gods (both will be expanded upon in the not-so-distant future incidentally, or so the VERY friendly people behind this game are stating) all blend together to create a deep and enjoyable experience. Literally the only downside to this game is it's lack of an online multiplayer system, though for what it's worth the bots are very human like and responsive as well.

Special shout out to the visual style of the game, it's simply fantastic, and the sound effects which make every attack seem to have a special kind of weight to it.

8/10, as petty as it sounds I'd bump it up to an easy 9/10 if it had online multiplayer simply because this is the kind of game that goes so well with a crowd of friends to play it with, and many such as myself rarely have the time (or in my case even spare controllers) to get a group together and crowd around a computer screen. Everything else, from the combat to the purchases to the monster evolution system is superb.

Early Access Review

We’ve all played RPG’s before with friends at our side, but what happens when your friends control the monsters instead? Developed by the two man team over at Powerhoof, Crawl is a local co-op dungeon crawler for up to four players, and provides the answer to that very question.

In a rather interesting turn of events, one of you controls the hero, slaying monsters, gaining levels, and buying loot, while the other 3 players use ghosts to possess traps or summon monsters with the simple goal of killing you to become the hero instead. The point of Crawl is to survive long enough to reach level 10, then activating a portal to the final boss encounter. The player that reaches and defeats the final boss first wins the game.

If you have local friends who frequent your house, Crawl is an insanely good time. Its short 30-minute games, combined with its accessible pick-up-and-play control scheme, make it ideal for parties or for larger groups of people to pass the controllers around. However, if you’re running solo, you’ll most likely grow tired of fighting the A.I. rather quickly and there isn’t anything to do after that.

Full review: http://wp.me/p2go2D-4Gd

Early Access Review

Crawl  delivers just what it promises: A local multiplayer crawler type game with superb art and a great style and feel to it. From what little I have played of it I would definitely recommend it.
The game is well balanced, with one player taking on the role of hero, while the other three play as the ghastly dwellers of the dungeon, aiming to defeat the hero for their own benefit and to regain their mundane form.
In terms of combat the game flows very well, loot and different weapons can be aquired throughout the dungeon, and can be unlocked as you progress. There are different active abilities that the hero can preform, all from AoE damage to your more typical combat rolls. There are also plenty of different monsters with varied playstyles, tactics and various evolutions for the opposing players to control. The spirits can also possess various traps with different effects throughout the dungeon.
As it is only in early access, I can't wait to see this game developed even further in the future with even more content.
Early Access Review\n\nA must-have for anyone that loves pumbling their friends. Definitely worth.

Early Access Review

This game is fantasitc. It is probably my most anticipated Indie game title that I have ever purchased.
