Even though the game is in early access, it still delivers a positive gameplay experience and has a lot of content. The developers spend a lot of time in the discussion forums reading over concerns and suggestions so that they can deliver the best possible gaming experience. I would say that the game is safe" to buy during the early access stage
date: but is a must have once it is completely finished."

Early Access Review

Wow, what a surprise. I'm not usually one to pick up early access games as I would prefer to play a finished project, but after seeing this on the Humble store, I  immediately fell in love with the pixel/glitch art style. I checked out the gameplay video and decided to give it a chance.
Crawl starts up as if it's an old school arcade game, asking you to insert coin and enter you initials. Up to four players can play via couch co-op (no online unfotunately, but I think the fast paced gameplay lends itself better to local co-op) using keyboard, mouse or controllers. One player starts as the human character advancing through the dungeon collecting money, loot or finding the exit to the dungeon. The other three player take control of ghosts who can summon creatures or possess traps in the dungeon with the purpose of destroying the human character. Once a ghost player has killed the human player, they become the human. End game happens once a human character destroys the main boss.
As you progress, your character levels up and can buy weapons and equipment that change the way the game is played. In between levels, you can upgrade the monster creatures you send out as a ghost, making the game more difficult as you progress. It's very nicely balanced and I never felt like one player was too strong or weak against other players. While this game is meant to be played with multiple players, I found single player with bots surprisingly challenging, and at times forgot I was playing against the computer.
I highly recomend Crawl if your looking for a frantic couch co-op game to play with your friends, or just looking for a fast paced arcade style game to play by yourself. With the added promise from the developers of more creatures, dungeons, and items to be added in the future, as well as the $10 price tag, you really can't go wrong with this one.

I don't advise buying early access games unless they are fun as-is. And this certainly meets that requirement! It is one of the most fun local multiplayer games that I've played since before I became a computer gamer.

This does NOT have online multiplayer. As the devs have said, if this a requirement for you just wait for more information. If not, it's a worthwhile purchase.

I thoroughly enjoy Crawl. The graphics and simple controls give a really nice asthetic feel to the game, like something you'd play on an old console. Despite it's apparent simplicity, Crawl is anything but.

The game handles the fast paced action of The Hero (you) being attacked by all of the Spirits (your friends) incredibly well. The team work potential of Spirits to destroy The Hero, using the huge number of combinations of items, monsters, and traps that exist gives the game a lot of replay value.

A few parts beautiful graphics, several parts chaotic action, one part slow motion, Crawl is a great game that will (probably) cement your bonds of friendship with friends.

Clever trash talk not included.

Early Access Review

While on the surface Crawl may not look like much, it only gives you short play sessions and the gameplay is pretty straightforward, it's way too plain.

YOU'RE DEAD WRONG

Crawl may only have short play sessions and generally simple gameplay, however, the experience that is delivered throughout that short period of time is like no other. You play as the monsters to regain your humanity or fight as a human to keep your humanity. This extremely unique multiplayer experience cannot be overlooked. The only real problem comes in with...limited multiplayer options. Fighting AI controlled bots is more entertaining than you might think however, the serious problem arises with there being only local multiplayer. Although you can play a smooth two-player match with one person on mouse and one on keyboard, online or at least LAN multiplayer would truly make this game much more enjoyable. All in all, the gameplay may be short-lived but it leaves you wanting more, and although multiplayer is still a bit of a problem, it still provides hours of entertainment.

Pros:
+Unique gameplay experience
+Outdated yet good looking Graphics
+Endless replay value
+Game is simple enough to be played just with a mouse, allowing for a smooth two-player match (As long as you have a keyboard as well)

Cons:
-Multiplayer is limited to local (Quite a drawback) May want to wait until it's finished before purchasing

Early Access Review\n\nWhen I saw the trailer for this game, admittedly it made me weak and sent a shiver down my spine. The idea and setting of the game is utterly marvelous. Not only creeping through a dungeon with your friends trying to cause your downfall, but with care, they can take that delicious chance of freedom from you is so very entertaining. I personally love the art style, it's suitable and really helps set the theme for this dark dungeon crawl. The controls are simple, yet very satisfying, every strike with a blade and every dodge to spare your life is as satisfying as any. Not to mention the monsters you encounter, some you love and some you hate, but that makes you fight so much harder just to make sure you do not see your grinning friend shout in success as he steals your humanity. Though many people have complained about an online functionality, I understand however am not too upset by it. If there is not going to be an online function however, I would like to see some improvements to the AI. Often I've found the AI to act in peculiar ways, like they're on a cycle, letting another AI or player get away with things completely at certain times and it's tremendously obvious when they do so. I'd like to see the AI be a little more dynamic and not quite so inclined to help each other, it is a desperate fight for freedom after all. Aside from that however, so far into the Early Access I am loving the game, and hope many more do. Absolutely  worth the price, and the fun to be had.

Early Access Review\n\nCrawl is the definition of party games to play when you want to start a fight with your friends. Crawl is a co-op(or single player with bots) retro arcade simulator fantasy dugeon crawler. Aiding yourself with powerups, spells and abilities, and tons of unique weapons, the hero must fight through levels and levels of dungeon against player coltrolled monsters. As you get stronger, so do the monsters. As a human player your goal is to reach level 10 and kill the boss(which is also player controlled). However, everyone else plays the roll of the monsters and traps in the dungeon which constantly evolve and become more and more difficult. If you are killed you become a ghost and your killer becomes the hero. See where this is going? This game has competition and rage written all over it. One can play a quick game within 15-20 min, but the longer the game lasts the more exiting it tends to be. The developers are constantly releasing new content and making the game better and better with each update. For anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers or simply wants a game to play with their friends, this game is for you.

Early Access Review

MAN, where do I start. Ok first of if you enjoy classic 8 bit style games or their modern counterparts such as Terraria, Risk Of Rain, Super Meat Boy, Shovel Knight, then I would take good hard look at Crawl.

What's so fun about it? For one it has a very fitting, nostalgic, well made soundtrack. You're given many controller options and the controls them selves are very simple and In addition, are very responsive. They don't feel goofy or sloppy. *UNLESS* you choose to use the mouse as your controller, I wouldn't recommend it.

The level design is randomized, you will never play a game and feel like you've been on a particular level before, it just doesn't get old. The scenery always seems fresh.

The game is stable I've played around 37 hours so far and bugs as well as crashes are rare. It's most likely not a game you're going to be frustrated by because it crashes every 20 minuets.

The AI is actually very enjoyable to play with, it's surprising how clever they can be at times which provides a highly entertaining experience. With few bugs to mention besides occasionally getting trapped it's a great addition which allows you to play offline any time.

I could go on about the large selection of weapons, unique items, buffs, monsters, mini bosses, bosses, statues, traps. But that would take a long ♥♥♥ time.  To keep this short, In the end, for $10 this game is dripping with content, and quality, and fun times.

The only thing that I'd warn of, is that the game isn't online multiplayer, only local multiplayer (as in) you plug in 4 controllers to one computer and you can play with 4 friends like a console.

Online would be a great addition but it's not currently avalible.

Great game. One of the best games I've ever played. This is an addictive, competitive, dungeon crawler that will keep you on the edge of your seat when fighting friends. Most of the monsters seem balanced and are very fun to use.

However...

Monsters Problems- The Green Shaman monster thing that summons the zombies need to be nerfed to hell and back. It's very very fast, and has so much health. Not to mention that the slime it leaves behind slows you down so much it's not even a fun challenge. The tentacle things need to have slightly lower health and weak attacks also. The one that is able to go underground and then come back up and attack you is way too ogrepowered. It need to have lower health or do less damage, or not be able to go underground as often. The other one's not as bad, but the tentacles it makes come from the ground are SUPER bulky and take up the whole screen! This game has a unique feel. It's really fast-paced and you go from being an aggressive villain to a defensive hero within seconds! Matches last about 30 minutes and the competitive and tense nature of these matches really is fun. Local multiplayer games are not very common on PC but this really works. I also love the aesthetics! The art style and animations are very smooth and reminescent of older games mechanics-wise. 9.5/10! I love this game.

Only improvement would be to adjust the pacing of the AI when in singleplayer, as soon as they are level 10 they try the boss, I wish they'd wait a little bit to get upgrades first.

Early Access Review

I play this game with my son on his account. Not sure what my play time will show on my account but I've played more than it will show. We own a ton of games in this genre. The local co-op, retro, throw everyone in the ring and fight each other type games. Stuff like Towerfall, Samurai Gunn, Gang Beasts, Nidhogg, BroForce Deathmatch, etc. Theey're a great style of game for when you have friends over. Everyone can grab a controller and get right to the fun. No wasting time. Crawl adds to this genre in a big way.

The concept is pretty genius. 1 player controls the hero while 3 other players control ghosts which can pocess" traps and mobs while the hero runs from room to room in the dungeon. The fun exists because the hero needs to kill the monsters to collect XP and level up. Once he gets to 10 he needs to find the portal room and portal to the boss. At which point the 3 other players take pocession of different parts of the boss and try to take out the hero and send everyone back into the dungeon. The catch comes when a ghost kills the boss
date:
he then becomes the hero and tried to level up his hero to 10. There are many other things to consider while leveling. Finding blood and turning it in to merchants sos you can buy weapons and spells and potions. Ghosts collect points to level up the monster they can transform into in certain rooms in the dungeon.

The whole game put together keeps everyone engaged and in it to win it not matter how far behind. First time playing my guy hit level 10 first but I never made it to the boss through the portal room. Another guy made it to the boss several times and died. The guy who ended up winning was in last the entire match.

I generally do not do EA but this one is a gem. This one should be fun to play for a long time as long as you have some people around to play with.

http://youtu.be/Cj8nZXmg8UY"

Early Access Review

Crawl is an awesome multiplayer (local) game in which you, your friends and AI will control up to 3 ghosts. The players will be competing for gold and experience while traversing a dungeon. One player will spawn as the hero, and the remaining players will start as ghosts. The currently alive player will move from room to room, coming across pentagrams in most rooms. The ghosts can activate these to summon one of 3 monsters chosen in a kit at the start of the game.

Should a ghost deal the killing blow on the player, they spawn as the hero and must continue the dungeon! Each floor has a shop and boss ring the player can interact with, as well as other wishing wells and a few other entitys to work with.

The combat is fun, there's plenty of weapons the store offers, plenty of artifacts to modify the character, as well as spells to get from the shop.

Pros:
A fun (currently local) fighting game for friends to challenge each other in.
Plenty of weapons to choose from, a good bit of item variation.
Lots of unlocks to encourage replayability.
Challenging bosses that force the ghost/players to work together to kill the hero/player
More content to come!
The combat is solid and fun.
Nice design for a minimalist/pixel game.

Cons:
While maps are randomly generated, there isn't any difference in backgrounds or themes at this time of review
The sound is very harsh and not appeasing at all.

Early Access Review

Well, well, well... Of all of the roguelike, couch co-op indie games out there, Crawl has to be my favourite. The atmosphere of the game is just creepy enough to send the willies up newcomers, not to mention the new intro cutscenes narrated by the magnificent Old Shrimpeyes. I don't know what that man eats, drinks or starves himself of to get that kind of voice, but whatever it is, I want it.
Intro and Atmosphere aside, Crawl is just a boatload of fun to play. I picked up the Steam Link recently and said box of goodness has proven itself to be quite good at processing these pixel-style games. It's situated in my living room, so I of course went on to have a real couch co-op experience with a few mates which consisted mainly of ghostly noises and violent screaming. The graphics are great, especially when running at 60fps as you get to watch the current human shifting fearfully from hall to hall before being set upon by rats, spiders and goblin grasshopper thingies, all of which are controlled by either bots or the people sitting next to you.
The best part is, if you haven't been human for a while, you gain Wrath every time the lucky fellow levels up, which in turn allows you to evolve your goblin grasshopper thingy into a rock-lobbing giant. This system of EXP for the living and Wrath for the dead makes the game a lot fairer and keeps things interesting in a long runthrough.
Overall, I'd recommend Crawl for anyone hankering for some old fashioned jolly cooperation; I can't remember what I bought it for because I was a pre-release funder, but whatever it costs now, it's worth it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is- and always will be, in my opinion, one of the best games of all time. So many hidden references and jokes, but yet incripted, et cetera as to stay in the same atmosphere, its mechanics, and gampeplay, and just about everything I can think of about this game is perfect. I mean, to think it is only £7, to think that it is only early access, well, in the future I cant even think on how they can improve the perfect, but Im sure Those 2 creative people down there will find a way, for whatever choice they make, even if they poke fun at a real religion, would be done in such a way nobody would care! The concept of the game is, when you start, everything is glitchy. >:D. Ok, so, it causes a good unsettlement at the start, thats ok. then you start playing with a friend. And then you realise the TRUE PERFECTION THE GAME IS!!!! I mean, I have a friend who owns it, and I am sharing it using the steam library, but I AM SO BUYING THIS GAME ANYWAY! You start as one of you a human, entering a place, and walking around, when there are pentagrams. Your friend, a ghost, goes up to them AND BECOMES A MONSTER AND YOU FIGHT AND THE MONTER KILLS YOU, AND THEN THE MONSTER BECOMES A HUMAN AND YOUR THE GHOST!!! THEN YOU LEVEL UP AND KEEP ON DOING THE SAME THING, AS DIFFERENT MONSTERS, AND THEN YOU GO TO THE NEXT FLOOR AND EVOLVE THEM UNTIL YOU BEAT A BOSS AND WIN! Unfathomably great, atmospheric and suiting music, insrutably satifsying and fun gampeplay, concept, et cetera. All in all, I rate this game: 11/8. Must buy. as soon as I get the money I am going to get another game for my own. Not because I cant play it, but so the develepors get the money they deserve.

P.S. when you call yourself something, name yourself HL3. that, on its own, is worth the £7.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the beginning, this game worth to play. It is a game which you can play with your other 3 friends-or bots if you have less friend, offline by using keyboard, mouse and two joysticks. One to be a hero and the other contrl the creeps(read the game instruction). It is not only kill their contrling creeps, but also cooperate with your other creeps which your friend's contrling,  against the hero to slow him go furder and earn the blood to upgrade your creeps, or just kill him-when you think he is suck, too weak in the other word- to be a hero-then you will be the hero. The hero would upgrade- of course -and also can buy the magic, item, weapon and so on to be more stronger. When the hero upgrade to lvl10, the hero can activate the charm to teleport to the final boss room. The boss would be contrled by other players, cooperate to kill the hero. If the boss kills the hero, the game will continue, otherwise, game over, the hero who kills the boss wins. The charm can only activate 3 times, after 3 times, game over also (I forget who will win in this case because no boss alives in our hands). Its really fun to play with your friends, more players, more passionate. Really, really worth to play. Go buy it and play with your girl friend now, and you will break up by my will, ha-ha.
CHINESE
先说，这游戏值得一玩。这是一个4人游戏，跟朋友一起玩特别嗨，除非你的朋友很少，那你可以跟电脑玩儿。这游戏就是一个人扮演英雄，其他人扮演怪。具体游戏是什么个玩法，自己看游戏介绍。我想说的是，这不只是一个杀怪的游戏，怪之间要懂得配合，把英雄当BOSS打。或者说，你觉得这英雄太菜了，就干掉他（抢人头！），自己当英雄。怪可以靠攻击英雄打出的伤害获得BLOOD来升级，英雄可以击杀怪物获得经验升级，然后获取金币去商店购买物品、魔法、武器等等用来加强自己的东西。10级之后就可以激活符咒开BOSS房打BOSS了，总共有3次挑战BOSS的机会，控制怪的玩家控制BOSS攻击英雄，杀了他之后会损失一次挑战BOSS的机会。谁干掉了BOSS，就谁赢。要是3次全失败，呃，反正我们没有失败过3次我不知道会发生啥事。跟基友们一起玩特别基情，人越多越基情，真心值得一玩。快买买买，然后跟你女朋友玩儿去。然后就会正如我所愿的分手的。哈-哈。

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of my new favorite games on Steam, hands down. Like a normal Dungeon Crawler, you go from room to room fighting off monsters. However in Crawl, the players play as the monsters, all trying to attack the main player. The goal of the game as a monster is to kill the human player and take their place, while the goal of the human is to kill as much as possible and gain XP points. You win the game if you're the player and you go into the boss room and destroy the boss. (The other players also control the boss too!) However, you may only do this at level 10. If the players fail to slay the boss 3 times, the player who fought the third time is removed from the game forever. (And I'm not kidding, it actually deletes your name!)

If you have friends locally, this is for you. Just grab a couple of controllers. And no, unlike 70% of steam games with controller support, it DOESN'T need to have XInput. The devs of this game were sure to incorporate as much controllers as possible. As long as it has a USB that you can stick into your computer the controller probably works. Did I mention the game only uses 3 buttons and a d pad? (2 not including the start button) Haven't tested it, but this should work in theory: http://www.amazon.com/Classic-USB-NES-Controller-PC/dp/B002YVD3KM

If you want one of the best local play experiences you'll ever have, buy now. Also the game devs are really active in the community pumping out updates like mad.

Positive Features:
-Up to 4 Players Locally
-Single player mode with AIs
-TONS of controller options
-Innovative control scene
-Active Devs (As of now)
-Low Price
-High Repeatability
-Cabinet mode (You may hook the game up to an arcade machine!)

Negative Features:
-No online support yet. May not come for a while. Don't buy the game hoping for online support, it's clearly not it's focus, although it may come in the future.


Overall, this game is wonderful locally. If you're having a party or just inviting friends over, this is a must have. It's still fun with bots, but not as good with other people, I haven't played much single player but I know it's kind of a mixed response, some like it and some don't. I like it though.

Also you can fight Gabe Newell. He hits you with his custom skinned digital knives. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, really polished.  Everything from the animations, to the special fx and sound is just killer.

The best part of the game is it brings back the co-op play back into gaming.    Even more impressive is if you don't have any friends, you can enable bots who are very skilled at the game.  Their behavior is pretty impressive.

It does take a little bit to get used to the controls and the timing/aiming of attacks.

The weapon/enemy power ups already seem pretty robust for an EAG.  I can't wait to see what other cool stuff they add.

My first play through with 2 players and no bots took 40 minutes, we were both able to upgrade out creatures to max level and got some pretty sweet weapons.  So there isnt too much content to the game, but the replay value is off the charts.

Worked great with my wired xbox 360 controller.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love this game, it has a really smooth feel to it, and the balance bewteen monster and human are perfect. It creates some really fun tims with friends even if it's not online multiplayer, and has unlimited replay-ability. But now for my recomendations to the developers. I beilive 3 things are needed to make this game even better than it already is, the first is just simply more enemies, bosses, and items, however I know that those are all in development already anyway. The second is online multiplayer, but that is a very time-consuming feature and maybe not worth it in the long-run. The third is a new team mode, where there is 2 humans at once, both of them with weakend health, and sharing gold though. And of course 2 monsters, both on the same team. So that when you kill one of the humans the other one also dies and swtiches to the monster, and both monsters become humans. This would make a really fun addition to the game, with the enjoyment of fighting against even AI with your freind on your team. And I think this should seriously be condisidered to add an awesome new element to an already amazing game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rating: 7.5/10

What I like:
-The game is awesome, it provides hours of fun if your alone and whenever I have friends over we play and we dont stop.
-I think that the graphics are very fun and I espically like the art on the all of the monsters.
-Being both sides are fun and enjoying to play, and I love how its easy to make a come back
-I adore the boss the fights and all the little things you have to micro manage, and the fact that you have to work with the other ghosts to bring down the heros is honestly one of the most fun things

What I didn't like:
-I think it would be awesome if this game supported online play, but I understand if the developer wasnt going for that.

Everything in this game felt smooth and awesome, and if I ever get behind and am the monster for too long I always can get ahead by getting better monsters and then becoming the hero. The cooprative play feels good and thought out, it may be simple but it feels great. I play this game whenever I am feelin really bored and want a challenge or whenever my friends are over. I fully recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great concept of a game carefully crafted and bundled into an easily set up multiplayer game. There is character progression, adversity which shifts constantly as other players take the role of the hero and the others take the role of the monsters trying to turn him into floor paste and some great bosses which allow for some nice action.

Overall, a solid concept. Now the reason for the no recommendation;

I played local multiplayer with a bot or two (not having more than one other person immediately available) and the result was a frantic scrabble after the AI, trying to figure out what to do. This itself did not take long, but the frantic scrabble continued on and on and on. Normally, frantic in a game is good, but this just felt like always playing catch-up and never progressing. At the end of each floor, regardless of character advancement, it always felt like we were not quite sure what had been achieved, what happened or what we were even trying to do. We continued on for a while, had a few boss encounters and played as both the monsters and hero a few times each. It was around the time my friend said I'm bored" that I realized that I was too and had just been forcing fun onto the session.

The ghost characters constantly felt like they were dragged from room to room
recommended: often never having the chance to even attempt the various awesome traps in the corridoors between some of the rooms. The blob drops were a nice touch
hoursPlayed: enabling the ghosts to stay in the action
voteText: but not overwhelm the hero too much with mobs. But it still felt a bit bland and it was hard to relate to any of the characters with the constant control switch (mostly with the AI bots getting in there 9 times in 10). Overall
helpfulPercent: for two of us playing with two bots
votesHelpful: it was not fun.\n\nOther people with three friends to play with may very well have an awesome time with Crawl
votesTotal: but I think it needs a little more balance
votesFunny: maybe some humor or something
commentsCount: anything to bring it to life. Players need something to work with to get fun out of a game. Other than that
column16: the devs have done an awesome job (love the boss intros
column17: they looked awesome!) and I hope I get chance to have fun with this in the future."
column18: September 27, 2014

Early Access Review

Gotta say, this game is just awesome.

Buy it and sit down with a couple of friends on the couch, grab four controllers and go crazy. Played it for about eight hours last night without really getting tired of it.

You can worship different gods, giving you a different set of enemies to control each game, you can buy new items, giving you a feel for different playstyles.

I look forward to seeing more from this game, because we're already sold. This is THE go to couch co-op game for me right now!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great..But its overpriced.

I feel like they really should have made more out of this game. It starts out great.. you trucking along and oh.. whats this portal.. hmm level 10 to use portal gotchya... then you make to level 10.. omg portal takes you to boss ... ok... kill boss... game over... 10 mins... beat the game... wtf i have only played the game for 1.8 hours and i have beat it like 6 times.

i get that this is supposed to be more of a couch game and a multiple person game but the bots do a good job.
The game play is fun. upgrading weapons is fun. and the currency system feels great.

but the game is SOOOOOO short. i was super pumped that the game was level based... then you kind of realize that each level is kind of the same... and it almost seems like they are random generated. so there is no outside... there is no travel or anything like that.  i would have loved to see this in a more open style with armor upgrading aswell.. toss in a minor storyline and some different worlds and more bosses and you have youself a hell of a game.


so... overall i would still recommend it... but i feel like 10 dollars is too much... 4 dollars seems more legit for the amount of gameplay you actually get out of it. but still pick it up for the expirence lol

I love this game. Amazing work done already.

and I'm very much looking forward to seeing how much more is going to go into this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl does what some other games fail at doing. It actually succesfully replicates the old retro feel of games.
Sitting down with a couple of friends, and having a good time. The mechanics of this game are great as well. The fac that you can evolve your monsters and hero keeps the game fun and exciting. Also, being given only 3 chances for the play to defeat the boss. It provides an insentive to keep playing through the floors even after you reach level 10 so you can truly defeat the boss. Another cool thing that you don't really see is players being able to controll the boss. This allows for cooperative fun even though it is the final.
Overall, this game is fun and I would highly recommend to anyone looking for a retro style game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Crawl is a very fun game. It is still in development though, but the devs have done a superb job of keeping in touch with their community and letting them know about what it is they're doing and planning to do. Content is released at an acceptable pace as well. They're a shining example of how these titles should be handled, at the moment. I've enjoyed this game immensely and that's without being able to get people together to play it with me on a regular basis. That's right, I'm having fun playing against the AI. I'm not saying that the AI is in anyway extraordinary, but I just find the game itself so fun that I don't mind playing by myself, even though this game shines the brightest with friends.

As of right now I can recommenced this game to anyone looking for a unique game concept and a fun party game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game so terribly hindered by lack of online multiplayer I cannot in good conscience recommend it. Singleplayer is nigh unplayable, especially given the poor tutorials, and the game is entirely designed around multiplayer, so no online option just brings this down to a wasted purchase.

I know netplay is a difficult thing for indies to add, but when the entire game revolves around it, and it's the #1 thing requested for over a year of early access, it really needs to be a priority. Especially in the PC market, local only is baffling for an entirely multiplayer game.

Will revise review if netplay becomes available, otherwise, absolutely do not recommend.
voteText: 26 of 66 people (39%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really cool concept but has a few things that I really dislike.

1) Only local multiplayer with no online match making.

2) Game moves too fast. Both the player and ghosts whiz through each room with no time to plan or strategize.

3) There isn't really anything going on in any rooms beside traps or fighting each other. No puzzles, etc.

4) Too many things happening on screen and can get very confusing when combined with everyone whizing in and out of the each room to the next.

5) No other types of levels or bosses.. Just the same dungeon map and end boss.

I'm wondering if it's a generational thing? I've really been there and done that as far as mashing a single attack button and killing pixelated monsters over and over and over. Got my fill of that 30 years ago.

I'm not accusing these particular devs of this, but, it seems to me that retro" 8-bit graphics and gameplay are starting to become synonomous with simple lazy game design.

Early Access Review

1st Impressions: Excellent party game, but stands on it's own as good as single player game.  Very, very fun.  Any criticism I have is in no way a deal-breaker.
Pros:
- Balance: Lots of attention seems to be paid to keeping it interesting w/ the power dynamic between players constantly shifting.  Getting your minions' butts kicked? You'll rank up monsters faster. Spent a bunch of time running around as the hero killing everyone else? Now you're reincarnated as an toothpick spitting inchworm. All this is done without feeling like it's simply picking on the person in the lead.
ADDITIONALLY, the end-game is satisfying regardless of outcome since everyone both worked for and against it the entire time.
- Pace: I'm impressed how well it allows for a leveling and item system while still keeping the gogoGOGOGO!GO!GO! mentality.  There always seems to be something for everyone to be doing.
- Mood & Atmosphere: The glitched out voice acting brings me right back to scratchy copies of Golden Axe played on poorly tracking TVs.  Pixel graphics can be an aquired taste, but I think it fits well and this game puts a cool spin on it (this kind of possessed game cartridge").

Cons (somewhat minor
date: but I hope can be addressed as the game develops )\n- Player confusion: With the unsaturated color palette it can be easy to lose track of your player.  This gets harder during big brawls when some people may be controlling the same type of minion.  Regardless
recommended: the learning curve is small.\n- Advancement & Unlocks: As it stands
hoursPlayed: the item and "God" unlocks after a session seem arbitrary.  Currently
voteText: they seem to be coming out of the glitched-out ether of the game (which is cool mood-wise)
helpfulPercent: but it might be nice to see as least know what's triggering them - Are they indeed random? Tied to playtime? In-game exploration?\n\nI've only played this a few hours but it is already well worth the price - for the single player experience
votesHelpful: let alone the strong party game this is!"

Early Access Review

I tried this with friends and it was an ok game. It was slightly difficult for them to pick up the mechanics of the game and once they realized what was going on it was a little late.

I only went through this game about 3 times so a little salt needs to be had here and I know I didn't unlock everything yet.

Gripes:
The game itself is fun and competitive but most of the time it was a little too one sided.

Once you pick up permemant stats from merchants it starts going down hill pretty quick for the opposing monsters because by the time you get the next merchant, you have at least died once and switch back again after (because they can't buy permenant stats on the same floor they have to fight off the next level of mobs on the new floor.) It was resolved quickly when blood fountains started to appear more often in the first rooms (They act as teleportation to merchant's room.) But by that time player who got ahead first early pretty much kept a mile lead.

Postive notes about the game:
The game has a small decent variety of weapons/spells/items, as you play the it through a couple of times the game unlocks more items/mobs/spells you can use in the next game which keeps it interesting. Mini-bosses are fun to play as.

Somethings I would tweak about the game.
Traps slightly more visible for players (it's mostly for the ghoul's benefit.) Sometimes I can run into a room and friends would not see the traps they could posses after their mob form has been defeated.

I was just thinking it would be better if there was gameplay option tweaks, speeds, respawnable items or demon circles, changing the RND for chests/mini-bosses/traps, how many ectoplasm slimes can be held by ghouls, stuff like that.

Possible additions to the game:
Death pits! Lava bits! Water world. (Different wall sprites, it does get monotonous after 11 floors to see the same green decaying stone walls.)
Holster/switch weapons? Most game controllers have more than 4 buttons...
Throw mechanic for player? Throw props? Hide in them?
Holding more than one spell? Requires switching delay.
More than one final boss?

Hero
The aim of the hero is to level up to level 10
date: activate the portal and defeat the boss monster. The hero can also buy stuff from the black smith and store including weapons
recommended:
buffs and special ability items.
Ghosts
The aim of the ghosts is to kill the hero and therefroe become the new hero. They do this by possessing traps and activating pentagrams to become monsters in the dungeon. The ghosts get viae points by other heroes leveling up to spend on evolving their monsters. Their is a good variety of monsters as of v0.3 with more to come. When the monsters hurt the hero they earn blood which they convert to gold to buy stuff when they are the hero.

This game is great! The graphics really aren't too bad, and besides, I vastly prefer well-made 2D graphics to fuzzy, badly made 3D graphics any day. Very fun gameplay, and I like the fact that you can, for once play as the traps as well as the monsters.

My only real problem with this game is the aiming, and the fact whatever you are shooting goes whichever way you are facing. This makes ranged monsters/heroes feel uncontrollable at times. I would like to see some more content, such as new monsters and equipment, as well as maybe a couple of new traps. I also think the Gatekeeper is a bit easy, and could perhaps have some more health.

Apart from that this game is AWESOME! I highly recommend it to anyone who likes dungeon crawl games, as well as Dungeons and Dragons players. By which I mean, of course, PROPER D&D, the Pen and Paper games, not that stupid Neverwinter game made by Perfect World. That game sucks.

Anyway, DEFINITELY a reccomendation. They are still bringing out more content for about another year, and after that the price is going up, probably to this games actual worth, about $20. Definitely get it soon!

Early Access Review

Crawl caught me entirely by surprise. The concept, gameplay and art style were all so fresh and unique that I was immediately hooked by this game. There are too few games in the world today that evoke the same emotions as the quest involved in playing a round of Crawl with your friends.
Firstly, as an early access game, I was astonished when I picked this up because I found little to no glitches or bugs and it was bursting with content right from the start. The community is also very much alive and the developers are simply phenomenal, always keeping you updated as to their progress and ideas for the game.
The gameplay is like nothing I've ever played with up to 4 players playing locally (3 as ghosts and one as a hero) attempting to become a level 10 hero and defeat the dungeons boss. The catch is that since there is only one hero at a time, if you are not playing as the hero, you are one of the 3 ghosts controlling the dungeons minions, traps and bosses attempting to kill the hero and whomever deals the killing blow becomes the next hero.
Games are generally fast-paced and frenetic yet the overall game round can take up to 30-40 minutes to play through depending on the players experience levels. The fact that the game is truly semi-cooperative in nature at all times is wonderful and keeps player interaction high. This is what makes local multiplayer gaming so wonderful to me and Crawl really delivers on that front. Many gamers have argued that they wished this game offered online support, and while I understand that not everybody has the opportunity to play with 4 players locally I really don't think this game would deliver the same experience if it were being played with people miles away on the internet instead  of your friends and family on the couch next to you.
While I absolutely love this game and how unique and just plain fun it is the one major frustration for me would have to be the fact that the monster who deals the killing blow becomes the next hero and not the monster who dealt the most damage or some other qualifier. This just seems unintuitive, unfair and unrewarding to the non-hero players and I really think this should at least be an alternative option for the game settings if not the standard. I have discussed this with other gamers and while I understand their points as to how making it the player who deals the last blow can work as a balancing mechanism for weaker players I've seen it create just as much imbalance and more importantly change the flow of play to where camping is encouraged for monsters so that they can prepare themselves to deal the killing blow instead of simply attack the hero relentlessly. I truly believe that there should at least be an alternative option available in the settings for the monster who dealt the most damage to become the hero because I find it silly for a game to inherently make one of its mechanics just frustrating for the players  and immediately turn them off the excitement.
Despite my one major criticism I have seldom found a game whose development has excited me as much as this one and I really hope that the developers consider my opinions on the game. Overall Crawl is definitely a game worth checking out for any gamer who wants to experience a new and exciting type of game and I highly recommend it if like me you are a huge fan of local multiplayer games that appeal to that childhood sense of playing arcade games and other video games side to side with your friends and family before the lonely Online Gaming era.

Highly recommended!

I expected this to be a very casual game when looking at the description, boy was I wrong (And loving it!)

Crawl gives you a very nice and expansive Roguelike to play around with and it lets you do it with your friends (Competetively!)

I was expecting it to be very basic in terms of features but to my pleasant surprise it does have a lot of different weapons and monsters as well as a lot to unlock (At the time of writing this I have not unlocked everything although I have found a number of different types of unlocks)

In short : Crawl is a kickass dungeon crawler that offers a lot of depth and an extreme amount of fun when  paired up with a couple of buddies on the couch

9/10!

Early Access Review

Ever since I've seen the teasers for this little game, I've been really eagerly waiting for its release. Final verdict is that it was definitely worth the wait, with the only disappointment being no online multiplayer (which hopefully comes). The whole concept is every fun and novel, in which all the maps seem to be procedurally generated as you play. One player starts off as the Hero, while the others play as three Ghosts, which have the ability to possess things throughout the rooms... such as pentagrams, for monster summons, and dormant traps, which can be utilized.

The object for the players is simple: Be the first to get up to XP Level 10 so you can open up the portal to face the final boss and fight for your escape. A Hero earns their experience by killing the opposing players who take monster forms, but there's also a second form of specialized experience, particularly useful to the Ghost players: Vitae. Every time a Ghost player causes damage to the current Hero, they earn this currency, which can be used in a variety of ways, like taking a warp to the floor's shop, pay tribute to an idol for quick cash, or... if you're feeling more offensive... use it to upgrade your monsters. That melee skeleton not cutting it for you? Upgrade it to a bow skeleton for heavier, ranged damage. Being an early access game, I can see there's still plenty more to be made for this game, so I can see this system being expanded on quite nicely. Even better, winning the game makes unlocks more things to use in the game, which helps increase the replay value here.

My only gripe is the lack of online multiplayer, which could make this game's popularity explode greatly, but even then... If you have four controllers to plug into your PC? Get this... NOW. It's definitely a riot of a local multiplayer party game. :>

Early Access Review

Here's a multi-part review discussing how the game works and then information about how my kids of various ages interact with the game.

-- How it Works --

The game is gorgeous and we all really love how it looks and sounds.

Up to 4 players play locally (2 minimum). 1 person plays as a human, the other 3 play as ghosts. The human is seeking gold and experience. Once the human grows up to experience level 10, they make go into a special realm and fight a final end-boss. If they win against the boss, they are the dungeon survivor.

The ghosts, on the other hand fly around grabbing orbs. Once they collect enough orbs they're able to drop simple slime monsters into the map. If ANY monster is in a room, then the doors lock and the human must slay them. In some rooms the ghosts may be able to use Monster Symbols to take control of a larger monster and directly fight against the human. In some rooms, the ghosts can possess traps and trigger them against the human. If a ghost kills the human, they come into the game as the human and the dead player returns as a ghost.

Here and there you'll find a shop where you can upgrade your spells, weapons, or passive abilities.

The entire purpose of the game is to play as a human long enough to get to level 10, then escape the dungeon by killing the boss.

What's really fun, is that you only get 1 chance to fight a boss monster per dungeon floor. If you fail, or are not a high enough level, then you most descend further into the dungeon before you can try again. Between each floor in the dungeon, the players can exchange the power they've gained (granted when the human levels up) to evolve their selections of monsters, to effectively increase the difficulty of the next floor of the dungeon.

This is definitely a lot of fun.

The final boss is a large beast that 3-players can take control of simultaneously against the human. If the players are on point, it's VERY HARD.

With only a few players, this game is very very simple. With 4-players actually trying to do a good job, the game is hectic and REALLY shines.

-- Family --

My 4-year old is a little unsure of the exact goals. But, she does like possessing items in the maps.  But, she gets tired of the game after 1 run-through.

The 9-year old has it all figured out and she does a great job.

We really like playing this game 4-player as a family. The 4-year old gets a BIT distracted sometimes. But, overall she's ok. I definitely had to take her through the game a few times 2-player with the explicit purpose of showing her around before she could understand it.

-- Overall --

I can't wait till they add more boss types and dungeon diversity. This game has fantastic style and I trust these developers to make the right decisions for the game.

Early Access Review

I love this game.

Crawl is a dungeon crawler/slasher, that brings in an awesome concept and a very nice twist to the gameplay. You, along with three of your friends (Or bots, if you so choose or have no one to play with), start right off the bat in the middle of a dungeon. One of you four is the hero, who must battle your three friends to first reach a high enough level to challenge the final boss, who, might I add, is also controlled by your three friends. The three who are not the hero control spectres, who take over dungeon traps strewn about, as well as transform into monsters with the use of bloody pentagrams on the floor of the dungeon. THAT'S RIGHT. YOU CONTROL MONSTERS. How cool is that?! For those of you who are like me, I've always thought that controlling the monsters in games would be completely, and utterly, awesome.

This game makes all your dreams come true. And with the granting of your wishes, the devs are still updating the game and planning for huge additions. This game will satisfy your hunger for blood, and then some. Something I love about this game is the local co-op. This game was made for you to butt heads against your closest friends, then claw into them. Not with a random guy you get paired with. However, while I really love this concept, I think that it would be a wonderful idea to add the option for us to do that. Especially if you have no friends who are interested in playing with you.

Also note that this game is Early Access. This is something very important to keep in mind. The devs are still working on this game. And from what they already have available, I would say it is definitely worth getting this game if you are into this type of game.

Early Access ReviewCrawl almost has a sort of Super Smash Bros feeling to it. Not in the mechanics, art style, or the way the game conceptualizes itself, but in how it affects you and your friends as you duke it out.

Truthfully I'm hard-pressed to think of a game that has been as much raw fun as this one with 3 other friends. Crawl is a work of art on the side of game mechanics -  a brilliant concept that has so far been executed extremely well and met my very high expectations.

More content is coming to the game, and it drives me nuts waiting for it. I definitely, like most others, feel that the game needs an online component, but the developers have said that they are seriously considering implementing that down the road.

If you have a group of friends that you hang out with in person who game, Crawl is an incredible game and one you won't regret getting!

I haven't read a whole lot of reviews, so I'm sorry if say some things that have been said a thousand times over.
That being said, I'd like to start off by saying that I love the concept of this game. All the items are super fun to combine and it's been fun seeing how long I can go with certain monsters without having to evolve them, and things like that.
Some things I'd think would be awesome if they were added:
-A Campaign: As fun as it is to grind through with a bot accosting me at every room, I would really enjoy some plot. It would be really cool if I was able to save my level and my items that I have at the time, and continue through the dungeons and such. I would definetly log a lot of hours on this game if such a thing were to exist.
-Gods: I'd like to kind of have a plethera of gods to choose from, with all their different minions and monsters. I'd also like to see some use of the actual gods themselves-- there are pictures of the gods, but no real reason to know what they look like. They're just a face. It would be really cool if there was a point in the game (of even a gamemode) where you get to play as the god you chose, and get to unleash your special kind of hell on your enemies.
-Heroes: As it stands now, when playing with four people, one person is pitted against three ghouls who get to try their best to rip their friend a new one. It would be nice to have some 2 v. 2 action, or maybe (when there's three players) two heroes and a ghoul. Just something to change it up and put it more in the players hands.
In addition to the Heroes suggestions, maybe you could have different hero types, or characters. Something to vary the gameplay.
It would also be pretty cool if people could submit their monster, item, and hero designs to 8bit-ify and have in the game.
Pretty much like workshop.


Just some ideas I've had while I've been playing-- I'm sure that half of what I've said are things you guys are already considering or even working into the next update. Either way, I'm excited to see where this game is headed!

Early Access Review\n\nThought it can be a lonesome crawl with the lack of online multiplayer, Crawl
date:
even in Early Access form, is a goldmine of local multiplayer value that shouldn't be missed.

In Crawl, you and 1-3 other players are all trapped in a dungeon guarded by a gargantuan monster. One of you will be a human fighter while the others are relegated to existing only as insubstantial phantoms. The hero is free to exlplore throughouth the dungeon, delving deeper into its catacombs as necessary to continue on in hopes of treasure, merchants, or a teleporter which can take the hero to the final boss room and either freedom or absolute destruction. As the hero moves from room to room, however, the phantom players can and will do everything they can to kill the hero, from possessing a variety of traps and summoning helper slimes to, most essentially, manifesting in the physical forms of any manner of beast from bear-trap summoning goblins to centaur archers to formidable gazer demons more than capable of slaying would-be-heroes. In the event that any phantom does kill the human opponent, they themselves will procure that player's humanity, spawinging as their own mortal fighter. This is the key pattern of the gameplay, with the hero being rewarded with experiencing points and the chance to purchase rare treasures from merchants nestled within the dungeon catacombs, while the phantoms are rewarded with stronger monsters and blood, which can later be turned into gold should they attain human form. The essential goal is to reach level 10 as the hero and, with the aid of an already impressive variety of unlockable weapons, potions, spells, and other items, reach the teleporter room instanced on each floor of the randomly generated dungeon and face the final boss in combat. The phantoms can possess parts of the boss's body to aid in the assault against the hero in an all-or-nothing battle. With victory, the hero is rewarded with freedom, but, should the hero be slain by his friends in his final assault, his name and likeness will forever be cast into ashes.

This game is still a work in progress but is still an easy product to recommend because all of the fundamental features and gameplay mechanics are already quite functional, entertaining, and polished. The core gameplay of killing your friends and becoming stronger in doing so is well-polished and, a few Early Access hiccups aside (including a lack of variety as of the time of this review and a forgivable level of question of balance with certain elements) is absolutely addicting in it's fast-paced flow of action, chance, and reward.

The game is themed well with what could be called a haunted-arcade vibe that keeps the visceral action light and helps the player appreciate the charming and beautifully rendered retro-style graphics. While the look could understandably be considered played-out" to some extent
hoursPlayed: but the atmosphere cast over the room by the up-tempo horror-midi soundtrack is both appropriate and exceptional.\n\nWith flawless controller support
helpfulPercent: quick 20-60 minute gameplay sessions and great mood I would absolutely recommend "Crawl" to any gamer who lives with other gamers or plays often with others in the same room. "Crawl" has no online support whatsoever and
votesHelpful: while the bots are functional and helpful if you have less than 4 people
votesTotal: playing alone feels like more of an empty practice session at best. This game is just a blast with friends that you can easily show someone whose never played before a controller and play well into the night without becoming bored
votesFunny: and that's only with the content available as of this very early access build. For 9.99 I personally think that a better value is difficult to find
commentsCount: even here on Steam."

This is probably one of the most fun games I've ever played. Being a fan of both roguelike adventure games and oldschool 8 bit action and never being able to get my fill of either, this game stopped up the hole in my soul. Competitve game fan? This is totally for you. Friendships have almost been ruined. I've made my girlfriend's little brother rage quit several times  (claims Berserk is op, wants you to remove it. plz dont.) The huge amount of unlockables keeps me coming back for more. The variety in weapon animations, awesome/funny monsters (huge fan of the flash my tentacles from under my robes" mind flayers :D) and interesting spell/item mechanics to keep everything spicy in the dungeon.

Early Access Review

An amazing game and I hope & pray it takes off. Looking forward to the additions they plan to make: more bosses, more monsters, more evolutions, more weapons (!) and more tilesets. A ton of fun even solo against bots; if you have your PC hooked up to your TV - and can swing the amount of controllers required - this looks like an amazing party game, moreso than even maybe Guardian Heroes for the Saturn.

I hate to admit it, but perhaps it would be easier if Crawl found a home on the PS4 or XBone. It almost seems like it was natively designed for those systems (i.e. local multiplayer setup). The fast-paced competitive nature of the game reminds me of Power Stone 2 where the sole goal is to become MORE AWESOME than your peers. There is a certain 'equilibrium' to the leveling scheme that I very much enjoy and everyone can be involved & have fun whether they are the protagonist, monsters, traps, or just marionetting the boss.

The pixel art-style does an amazing job of illustrating the action on-screen and also suggests careful choices of form and color. The level design of the dungeons (as mentioned before, they are planning more) feels like a fun slog through a Hero Quest scenario only not in boardgame iteration. Do I recommend getting it as it exists currently? Yes. Will it be better after it has time to ferment? Double yes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt takes a few minutes to get used to, but once you start to understand how to play, it's a blast. I haven't played with others, and I hope online multiplayer will be available someday. I can see this being a great couch VS game.

Early Access Review\n\nCrawl is an amazing and very fun dungeon crawler. It can be played up to four players, one person being the hero, and the other three being ghosts. The ghosts try to kill the hero by taking over objects or using a demon circle to summon a monster to fight the hero with. If one of the ghosts kill the hero, the ghost that got the killing blow will become the new hero. At the end of every floor the ghosts will get points every time a hero leveled up, and they get to use the points to evolve their monsters. While you're the hero; you try to get to level 10 so you can open a portal to the final boss. If you kill the boss (Which the ghosts will control) you win. If not, you'll be kicked out of the portal and have a small amount of health left. If the boss isn't beaten after three tries its game over and the ghosts win. I absolutely love this game and can’t wait for the finish product.

I wouldn't normally review an Early Access game but this deserves it because it 'works'. There are no problems with this release from a technical perspective, all that's missing is some content which the devs are / will be adding.

What I love about this game is that a 'game'. Almost like a board / card game, the principles and mechanics are the same each time you play but the enjoyment and experience each time (which takes 10-20 minutes) is unique.

This is not a co-op game, it's versus; a game in which you and up to three other AI or friends must battle it out to reach level 10 and defeat the boss. Only one player can be 'alive' at one time and the others must kill them by spawning as monsters or using traps to hinder the other's progress.

Fantastic little game and I look forward to seeing what other additions are made.

Last night I had some friends over at my place for dinner and afterwards we decided to play a round of Crawl.

We had such a load of fun! We had 4 players, 2 with xbox controller, 1 with the xbox controller from the guitar hero drumkit and one (who despises controllers) on the keyboard. First they made the mandatory jokes about the pixely graphics and how it made their eyes bleed, but in the end the gameplay really made up for it.

So, in this rogue-like game you are an adventurer trying to survive a maze of rooms and monsters (your friends) on a quest to defeat Kurok, the final boss. So while you are making your way through the rooms, your friends control incorporeal ghosts that can spawn monsters and possess traps. In some rooms pentagrams appear that allow a ghost to materialize into one of his monsters (randomly chosen) and try to gain back his mortality by defeating the hero. The one who delivers the final blow gets to play the hero.

Overall, everyone got to play the hero for a while.. except me. But that's actually not a bad thing! Once you reach the trapdoor of a floor you get to the next stage and before starting, every player can upgrade his monsters. You get upgrade points (or vitae") based on how many levels the other players gained

Early Access Review

Ever since I've seen the teasers for this little game, I've been really eagerly waiting for its release. Final verdict is that it was definitely worth the wait, with the only disappointment being no online multiplayer (which hopefully comes). The whole concept is every fun and novel, in which all the maps seem to be procedurally generated as you play. One player starts off as the Hero, while the others play as three Ghosts, which have the ability to possess things throughout the rooms... such as pentagrams, for monster summons, and dormant traps, which can be utilized.

The object for the players is simple: Be the first to get up to XP Level 10 so you can open up the portal to face the final boss and fight for your escape. A Hero earns their experience by killing the opposing players who take monster forms, but there's also a second form of specialized experience, particularly useful to the Ghost players: Vitae. Every time a Ghost player causes damage to the current Hero, they earn this currency, which can be used in a variety of ways, like taking a warp to the floor's shop, pay tribute to an idol for quick cash, or... if you're feeling more offensive... use it to upgrade your monsters. That melee skeleton not cutting it for you? Upgrade it to a bow skeleton for heavier, ranged damage. Being an early access game, I can see there's still plenty more to be made for this game, so I can see this system being expanded on quite nicely. Even better, winning the game makes unlocks more things to use in the game, which helps increase the replay value here.

My only gripe is the lack of online multiplayer, which could make this game's popularity explode greatly, but even then... If you have four controllers to plug into your PC? Get this... NOW. It's definitely a riot of a local multiplayer party game. :>

Early Access Review

Here's a multi-part review discussing how the game works and then information about how my kids of various ages interact with the game.

-- How it Works --

The game is gorgeous and we all really love how it looks and sounds.

Up to 4 players play locally (2 minimum). 1 person plays as a human, the other 3 play as ghosts. The human is seeking gold and experience. Once the human grows up to experience level 10, they make go into a special realm and fight a final end-boss. If they win against the boss, they are the dungeon survivor.

The ghosts, on the other hand fly around grabbing orbs. Once they collect enough orbs they're able to drop simple slime monsters into the map. If ANY monster is in a room, then the doors lock and the human must slay them. In some rooms the ghosts may be able to use Monster Symbols to take control of a larger monster and directly fight against the human. In some rooms, the ghosts can possess traps and trigger them against the human. If a ghost kills the human, they come into the game as the human and the dead player returns as a ghost.

Here and there you'll find a shop where you can upgrade your spells, weapons, or passive abilities.

The entire purpose of the game is to play as a human long enough to get to level 10, then escape the dungeon by killing the boss.

What's really fun, is that you only get 1 chance to fight a boss monster per dungeon floor. If you fail, or are not a high enough level, then you most descend further into the dungeon before you can try again. Between each floor in the dungeon, the players can exchange the power they've gained (granted when the human levels up) to evolve their selections of monsters, to effectively increase the difficulty of the next floor of the dungeon.

This is definitely a lot of fun.

The final boss is a large beast that 3-players can take control of simultaneously against the human. If the players are on point, it's VERY HARD.

With only a few players, this game is very very simple. With 4-players actually trying to do a good job, the game is hectic and REALLY shines.

-- Family --

My 4-year old is a little unsure of the exact goals. But, she does like possessing items in the maps.  But, she gets tired of the game after 1 run-through.

The 9-year old has it all figured out and she does a great job.

We really like playing this game 4-player as a family. The 4-year old gets a BIT distracted sometimes. But, overall she's ok. I definitely had to take her through the game a few times 2-player with the explicit purpose of showing her around before she could understand it.

-- Overall --

I can't wait till they add more boss types and dungeon diversity. This game has fantastic style and I trust these developers to make the right decisions for the game.

I love this game.

Crawl is a dungeon crawler/slasher, that brings in an awesome concept and a very nice twist to the gameplay. You, along with three of your friends (Or bots, if you so choose or have no one to play with), start right off the bat in the middle of a dungeon. One of you four is the hero, who must battle your three friends to first reach a high enough level to challenge the final boss, who, might I add, is also controlled by your three friends. The three who are not the hero control spectres, who take over dungeon traps strewn about, as well as transform into monsters with the use of bloody pentagrams on the floor of the dungeon. THAT'S RIGHT. YOU CONTROL MONSTERS. How cool is that?! For those of you who are like me, I've always thought that controlling the monsters in games would be completely, and utterly, awesome.

This game makes all your dreams come true. And with the granting of your wishes, the devs are still updating the game and planning for huge additions. This game will satisfy your hunger for blood, and then some. Something I love about this game is the local co-op. This game was made for you to butt heads against your closest friends, then claw into them. Not with a random guy you get paired with. However, while I really love this concept, I think that it would be a wonderful idea to add the option for us to do that. Especially if you have no friends who are interested in playing with you.

Also note that this game is Early Access. This is something very important to keep in mind. The devs are still working on this game. And from what they already have available, I would say it is definitely worth getting this game if you are into this type of game.

1st Impressions: Excellent party game, but stands on it's own as good as single player game.  Very, very fun.  Any criticism I have is in no way a deal-breaker.
Pros:
- Balance: Lots of attention seems to be paid to keeping it interesting w/ the power dynamic between players constantly shifting.  Getting your minions' butts kicked? You'll rank up monsters faster. Spent a bunch of time running around as the hero killing everyone else? Now you're reincarnated as an toothpick spitting inchworm. All this is done without feeling like it's simply picking on the person in the lead.
ADDITIONALLY, the end-game is satisfying regardless of outcome since everyone both worked for and against it the entire time.
- Pace: I'm impressed how well it allows for a leveling and item system while still keeping the gogoGOGOGO!GO!GO! mentality.  There always seems to be something for everyone to be doing.
- Mood & Atmosphere: The glitched out voice acting brings me right back to scratchy copies of Golden Axe played on poorly tracking TVs.  Pixel graphics can be an aquired taste, but I think it fits well and this game puts a cool spin on it (this kind of possessed game cartridge").

Cons (somewhat minor
date: but I hope can be addressed as the game develops )\n- Player confusion: With the unsaturated color palette it can be easy to lose track of your player.  This gets harder during big brawls when some people may be controlling the same type of minion.  Regardless
recommended: the learning curve is small.\n- Advancement & Unlocks: As it stands
hoursPlayed: the item and "God" unlocks after a session seem arbitrary.  Currently
voteText: they seem to be coming out of the glitched-out ether of the game (which is cool mood-wise)
helpfulPercent: but it might be nice to see as least know what's triggering them - Are they indeed random? Tied to playtime? In-game exploration?\n\nI've only played this a few hours but it is already well worth the price - for the single player experience

Early Access Review\n\nI find myself drawn to the dark and Lovecraftian backstory. Watch the tailers, the narrator (both voice and script) set the tone PERFECTLY. Play this game, alone or with friends. Everyone clustered around and out for blood is a blast, and I found myself smiling as I cursed my cruel friends for bleeding me like a stug pig. I grinned ear to ear thinking how that meat suit would soon be mine again. I'm reminded of the late-burning get togethers of my childhood. It WILL get more stuff, and what it has is awesome. 10/10 would've payed double the asking price.

Early Access Review

This game is great! The graphics really aren't too bad, and besides, I vastly prefer well-made 2D graphics to fuzzy, badly made 3D graphics any day. Very fun gameplay, and I like the fact that you can, for once play as the traps as well as the monsters.

My only real problem with this game is the aiming, and the fact whatever you are shooting goes whichever way you are facing. This makes ranged monsters/heroes feel uncontrollable at times. I would like to see some more content, such as new monsters and equipment, as well as maybe a couple of new traps. I also think the Gatekeeper is a bit easy, and could perhaps have some more health.

Apart from that this game is AWESOME! I highly recommend it to anyone who likes dungeon crawl games, as well as Dungeons and Dragons players. By which I mean, of course, PROPER D&D, the Pen and Paper games, not that stupid Neverwinter game made by Perfect World. That game sucks.

Anyway, DEFINITELY a reccomendation. They are still bringing out more content for about another year, and after that the price is going up, probably to this games actual worth, about $20. Definitely get it soon!

Early Access Review

Crawl caught me entirely by surprise. The concept, gameplay and art style were all so fresh and unique that I was immediately hooked by this game. There are too few games in the world today that evoke the same emotions as the quest involved in playing a round of Crawl with your friends.
Firstly, as an early access game, I was astonished when I picked this up because I found little to no glitches or bugs and it was bursting with content right from the start. The community is also very much alive and the developers are simply phenomenal, always keeping you updated as to their progress and ideas for the game.
The gameplay is like nothing I've ever played with up to 4 players playing locally (3 as ghosts and one as a hero) attempting to become a level 10 hero and defeat the dungeons boss. The catch is that since there is only one hero at a time, if you are not playing as the hero, you are one of the 3 ghosts controlling the dungeons minions, traps and bosses attempting to kill the hero and whomever deals the killing blow becomes the next hero.
Games are generally fast-paced and frenetic yet the overall game round can take up to 30-40 minutes to play through depending on the players experience levels. The fact that the game is truly semi-cooperative in nature at all times is wonderful and keeps player interaction high. This is what makes local multiplayer gaming so wonderful to me and Crawl really delivers on that front. Many gamers have argued that they wished this game offered online support, and while I understand that not everybody has the opportunity to play with 4 players locally I really don't think this game would deliver the same experience if it were being played with people miles away on the internet instead  of your friends and family on the couch next to you.
While I absolutely love this game and how unique and just plain fun it is the one major frustration for me would have to be the fact that the monster who deals the killing blow becomes the next hero and not the monster who dealt the most damage or some other qualifier. This just seems unintuitive, unfair and unrewarding to the non-hero players and I really think this should at least be an alternative option for the game settings if not the standard. I have discussed this with other gamers and while I understand their points as to how making it the player who deals the last blow can work as a balancing mechanism for weaker players I've seen it create just as much imbalance and more importantly change the flow of play to where camping is encouraged for monsters so that they can prepare themselves to deal the killing blow instead of simply attack the hero relentlessly. I truly believe that there should at least be an alternative option available in the settings for the monster who dealt the most damage to become the hero because I find it silly for a game to inherently make one of its mechanics just frustrating for the players  and immediately turn them off the excitement.
Despite my one major criticism I have seldom found a game whose development has excited me as much as this one and I really hope that the developers consider my opinions on the game. Overall Crawl is definitely a game worth checking out for any gamer who wants to experience a new and exciting type of game and I highly recommend it if like me you are a huge fan of local multiplayer games that appeal to that childhood sense of playing arcade games and other video games side to side with your friends and family before the lonely Online Gaming era.

Early Access Review

Ever go to improv night at a local comedy club? Notice all the actors are trying to steal the show? Crawl is just like that – with chunky bloody monster bits. And friends.

Crawl encourages us all to be narcissistic actors. Each player's motivation to take the spotlight keeps the play going. Crawl's designers demonstrate that couch-multiplayer and improv-theater go together better than Oreos and organic-whole-milk. Go on, be a Prima Donna. It's okay. Kill the hero. Take their place!

Taken from: http://plus10damage.com/blog/2014/9/11/improv-theater-of-the-future-crawl-preview

Early Access Review\n\nIt takes a few minutes to get used to, but once you start to understand how to play, it's a blast. I haven't played with others, and I hope online multiplayer will be available someday. I can see this being a great couch VS game.

Early Access Review\n\nCrawl is an amazing and very fun dungeon crawler. It can be played up to four players, one person being the hero, and the other three being ghosts. The ghosts try to kill the hero by taking over objects or using a demon circle to summon a monster to fight the hero with. If one of the ghosts kill the hero, the ghost that got the killing blow will become the new hero. At the end of every floor the ghosts will get points every time a hero leveled up, and they get to use the points to evolve their monsters. While you're the hero; you try to get to level 10 so you can open a portal to the final boss. If you kill the boss (Which the ghosts will control) you win. If not, you'll be kicked out of the portal and have a small amount of health left. If the boss isn't beaten after three tries its game over and the ghosts win. I absolutely love this game and can’t wait for the finish product.
Early Access Review\n\nSo much fun to play with friends

Early Access Review

In this game's current state,  couch gamers with a few controllers will enjoy it a lot.  I've played this game both with a keyboard and with a controller--the controller wins (but the keyboard still fells okay).

The game has tight controls and an amazing aesthetic that puts everyone in the right mood. An easy to understand upgrades system and easy access to 'tips' before each floor allow for nearly anyone to learn the game very quickly.

I enjoyed playing it with my friends, and I plan to play it even more... I just hope they continue to add features/upgrades to make the $10 worth it (it is always a gamble with Early Access titles).

It's already totally playable, and once more content is in the game I forsee hours and hours of fun unlocking things and stomping your friends! Only local multi with friends, but if you have some controllers, get playing this right away! Easily worth the price. Enjoy!

The wait was up and I finally got to sit down and start playing it with my cuz. Everything was complete audio and visual bliss.
The game delivers on so many levels even if you're forever alone" the bots implemented will keep you busy til you make some real friends.
I love the local multiplayer being a kid of the SEGA/SNES era and the game plays out  like its destined to be classic.
It's fast paced and exciting and will have you and your friends resorting back to that primal competitive nature. A must have party game and a beautiful homage to it's genre."

This is an absolutely fantastic multiplayer game! And it's not bad with bots either. One player is randomly selected as the hero and the others as ghost who can spawn minions at certain points or possess traps and statues. The object for the hero is to reach level 10 and take on the boss who is also controled by the ghosts. Whenever the hero levels up the ghosts gain vitae which is used to level up their minions and similarly for every bit of damage they do to the hero they earn blood which can be exchanged for goal in the hero's shop so the hero can remain competative.
The game is well balanced and extremely polished. I look forward to the updates!
